Overall, extremely pricey.  But good food and service.  If you're not afraid to spend $30-$60 a person give it a shot.
author: Brian K.

description: My boyfriend and I went to North Beach for dinner since the lady at the front desk of our hotel recommended it to us.  I was a bit disappointed.  The food wasn't terrible but it wasn't spectacular.  We had their famous prosciutto with melons, tagliatelle bolognese and spaghetti carbonara (their house speciality).  Both the prosciutto and carbonara were waaaay too salty for me.  I didn't touch my boyfriend's bolognese because I felt really full and bloated after consuming my spaghetti.  I wouldn't recommend this restaurant to anyone.
author: Anna Y.

description:
They have great wine choices if you're into that sort of thing but I only have one word: grappa!

Our waiter was really fun and patient even though we were the only people at the restaurant and stayed a little beyond closing time. The food was really good - especially my gnocchi :)

I adore this place!
author: Hannah T.

description:
I strongly do NOT recommend North Beach restaurant because the waiter stole from us by increasing his own tip, and because the food was mediocre and overpriced.
We dinned on 10/4/2014.

The waiter, Hadji, stole from us.  He increased the tip on our credit card bill beyond what we had signed for.  I called and complained, and was told by management (Norris I believe) that things like this happen.  

No apology, she me that it's comon for their waiters to increase their tips when there's multiple checks for a table.  Hadji had increased the tip on our payment to match what someone else at the table had paid.  I told her this was stealing, and she wasn't fazed by that.

And, the food was mediocre and overpriced.  Hadji raved about their prosciutto, but it was leathery and hard to eat.  We just had some at home that we bought from Lucky's supermarket in a package, and it was way better than North Beach Restaurant's prosciutto.   

Stay away!!
author: Jason S.

description:
Quite pricey, but if you want a classic (and expensive) North Beach experience go here, if you want a modern foodie take, then this is not really your sorta place.

My father was visiting and he wanted to go to an Italian restaurant in North Beach he had eaten at decades ago. So we walked into many foyers looking for the one and North Beach Restaurant was it.

The service was flawless, and was designed to make you feel like you were in North Beach back in the day. "Bellissima" and "Signoria" were common phrases used by our server, but it was not cheesy, it was charming. 

The pappadelle with shrimp smothered in vodka sauce was divine. The caesar salad was straight forward, no frills, tasty. The wine the server recommend was perfectly paired with what I ordered.

This is definitely a special occasions restaurant. I could tell my dad was inventing special occasions just to come back again.
author: Natalie J.

description:
Meh. Came here for a birthday dinner because Tommaso's was way too crowded, so my friend called here and the host said he could seat them immediately. I stayed behind to wait for a friend when I get a call telling me they won't sit us until everyone's there. That's okay but what I don't understand is they sat the 5 of us at a table meant for 4, and 3 were there already...would it really have looked THAT bad? No, I don't think so. Instead, we stood around for over half an hour with that promise of immediate seating being flung out the door as soon as we walked in. 

The food was okay, but I've had better. I got the Linguine w/ Fresh Clams in White Wine sauce....it was good, but I've had better. The clams didn't seem too fresh, and the White Wine sauce was watery and a bit too salty. It felt and looked like something I could have made at home for half the price and twice the freshness.

The service was actually pretty good, the waiter took time to explain stuff not on the menu as well as things we might not understand. Food came out pretty quick. 

But the bill...my God, the bill. $250 and most of that stuff could have been made at home for at less than half the price. I felt bad for my friends that paid, they had to split a horrendously overpriced bill. I would have been okay if the food WOWED me, but it did not come close to doing that. 

What really made me give this rating is the douche of a host that tries to be funny but ends up being rude. I don't care to repeat his crap here but honestly I wanted to punch the guy, but our table was finally ready and I didn't want to get kicked out or arrested. Maybe I don't get "Italian" humor, but generally when you insult your guests, funny or not, you deserve to lose business...and that's pretty much what they've done with me.
author: Alfred D.

description: Not flexible or accommodating with reasonable requests.  Crab cocktail was watery.  Will not be coming back to this restaurant.
author: Nicole G.

description: I asked for a med rare steak and got a well done somewhat tough and dry meat. The service was ok until another larger group sat down. Then our service was zero! Staff was friendly and worked with us on some issues with professionalism. The valet parking guy was a total jerk. He accused us of not eating at the restaurant and demanded a food receipt before getting my car. He was going to charge me double if I didn't have a receipt. And he demanded a tip! I told him his customer service and attitude was poor and unprofessional. In the end I didn't tip him based on his attitude. He became irate and started yelling at me in Italian and English and stomped off like a little kid. Way to go North Beach...such a class act!
author: Paul T.

description:
Came here straight from work to meet up with the guys after they waxed Cigar Aficionado at the nearby Occidental Cigar Club.  I remembered how much I disliked this area when I stepped inside and was almost caught in a stampede of suits trying to exit the restaurant.  So my bias against the Marina not withstanding, I'll try to provide a useful description.

FOOD:
Starters:
--Cesar Salad: standard, a little on the tangy side.  I told Marco to go heavy on the pepper; too heavy, I couldn't taste anything but pepper
--Farinata da lucca: thick soup with pureed beans and polenta.  So thick our waiter thinned it out by drizzling olive oil over it.

Entrees:
--Porchetta al Barolo: pronounced Pork-etta.  Roasted pork loin served with sauteed potatoes and haricots verts all resting on a thick layer of gravy.  I resisted the urge (and failed) to call it 'Porketta Pig'.    
--Sea Scallops sauted in a white wine mushroom sauce was a bit bland and the three smallish scallops sliced in half to make you think you're getting more than you were--not flavorful enough to warrant the $30 price tag.

Dessert:
--Tiramisu: hard to mess up this timeless dessert.  
--Lemon Sorbet: chosen to clear my palate but wasn't necessary as my palate wasn't wowed by any bold flavors.

SERVICE:
Marco was the quintessential trattoria-style waiter.  Attentive service in which 'grazzi's and 'prego's abound, he politely addressed us Signora and Signore.  Too bad his charm was lost in a place that failed to impress.  

COST:
Our party of four spent about $250 on a 3-course meal of soup/salad, main course, desert and coffee.  

BEST PART OF THE EVENING:
The poor valet was sweatin' bricks with one patron after another waiting for "the black Mercedes 500SL"--emphasis on the 500SL,  "the silver Porsche Roadster"--emphasis on the Roadster.  Without missing a beat, I said "Brown Ford Pinto"--emphasis on the Pinto.    You know how people say, "He just did a double take" but by the time you look you miss the double take? I actually saw the guy do a double take.  My husband--bless his heart--failed to see the humor in my snarkiness and intervened with the correct car description.
author: Joc V.

description:
So, to be fair, I didn't actually eat here. But I did try. I walked into the restaurant on Saturday evening looking for a table for 3. I was told to hang on for a second because I did not have a reservation. Then while I am waiting, an older couple waltzed in and were seated right in front of my face. The host then looks at me and says he has no room. 

"No of course not, once you seat a couple that saunters in right after me!"

Thanks but no thanks to this place. If you want to get good service and be treated well-I don't suggest going here unless you are going to pass their test of approval.
author: Mandy L.

description: Great service; Nice sidewalk seating and elegant decor. Delicious gluten free pasta! I had the fusilli pasta with meat sauce.The servers are old school and super polite. You feel like you walked right into Florence Italy.
author: Karen S.

description:
We went for lunch with our kids (10,11) and it was fantastic.  More of an authentic Italian place, not the standard pizza joint.  The service was excellent, and it was a welcoming atmosphere.  The presentation isn't anything fancy, but the food was delicious.  My wife's favorite meal of our trip.
The Caesar salad was one of the best I've had, and the grilled Halibut was fresh.  My kids shared a pasta dish.  Even with 2 glasses of wine, the bill was very reasonable.
author: Robert B.

description:
3.5
Came here with my aunt, uncle, and cousins family and it was good to see them.

Anyways when we arrived, various breads were served. Then we started off with mussels, prosciutto + melon (basically 2 pieces of cantalope), and fried calamari appetizers. Mussels were unremarkable, the calamari was fried properly, and the prosciutto (one of the house specialites) was not too salty and the texture was almost melt in your mouth.

For the main course I got the pasta della casa which had mushrooms, and very small bits and pieces of veal and prosciutto. The wine sauce complimented the pasta well but I wish there was a little more meat in it. Overall though it was a decent dish that I would not mind getting again.
My brother got the veal with mushrooms which was very tender and flavorful. Sorry I dont remember the actual name but I think the veal in general is a safe bet here. I also tried some of the salmon which was ordinary. Appetizers ranged ~$15 while the dishes varied from $20-$40.

Dessert consisted of tiramisu and some kind of alcoholic tasting pudding. Both were below average for the price (~$10 each). Apparently the tiramisu here did not have mascarpone cheese so I would avoid dessert here for sure.

Overall a very nicely decorated restaurant with excellent service but the food was just slightly above average and with a $$$ price tag, I probably will not be coming back.
author: Robert Y.

description:
First let me say everything I ordered was excellent.

My problem with this restaurant was the waiter. While the guys up front were very nice and friendly; I had Snobby McGee for my waiter;  black slick backed hair who had the weirdest voice ever. I hate admitting to watching this movie but he looked and sounded like Andy Richter's character from the Mary-Kate and Ashley Olson movie  "New York Minute".

I was on vacation by myself. But I still like going to restaurants. Unfortunately; he seemed to pay attention to the couples more than me. He asked the couples how their food was but not once did he ask me. I usually dont want waiters to be on top of me but not to completely ignore me. Just once throughout the evening I'd like to be asked how it's going. While everything I ordered came quickly; I had to get his attention if I wanted anything. I sat in front of the dessert menu for a good amount of time before he finally asked me in an annoyed tone if I "would like some dessert" I was liking some dessert five minutes ago! He also corrected the way I pronounced Cabernet Sauvignon.

What really bugs me is I shouldn't be treated as a second class citizen just because I was by myself.  I usually feel guilty when I eat by myself and overtip 20% or more for good service to make up for the fact that I order less than a usual table being one person. Since he chose to be Snooty Mcgee; I only gave the standard 15%. Some may think even that may be too generous based on my review but he was efficient and got everything I ordered fast to my table despite his snobbishness. 

Despite all this the food was excellent and I might even go back. I'd just ask for a different table if I got that same waiter again.
author: Alan S.

description: I love this place! Most of the waiters have been there for decades; the menu has variations on two of my favorites: petrale sole and veal cutlets. I've enjoyed prosciutto and melon, too. Portions are adequate in size, and quality of meat is very good. The chef has good ideas, has put his name on certain creations and knows that all "Italian food" does not need a thick coating of red sauce and melted cheese! Entree accompaniments are usually sauteed greens and oven roasted potatoes -- very nice. A word about the patrons: people go there, over and over, to eat a good dinner and enjoy conversation. There is no excessive noise; people talk; they do not scream as is common in a closeby restaurant. Every time I'm in San Francisco I go there at least once.
author: Marilyn B.

description:
My friend and I were looking for a good italian restaurant in North Beach and someone pointed us to North Beach the Italian Restaurant. Go figure. 

It didn't disappoint. The food was plentiful and delicious. We had our meal served up family style. We must have tried 10 different things and nothing disappointed. The wine list was thorough and the ambience was great. Great place to take a date. Do I have any takers?

The service was great. There were no less than 5 people tending to us the whole time. It was very classy and traditional. 

Why are you still reading this? Go there.
author: David N.

description: We came for lunch to little Italy and soon determined that many of the yelp high rankings were closed but one of the ones on our list was open....north beach restaurant.  We were seated quickly.   Marco, our waiter was a pro....making great recommendations, making my wife feel queenly, and being very attentive.. Yes service was very good as was the lasagna and ravioli.  Since my wife is Italian we are very discerning on Italian food and we were not disappointed.  Thanks, Marco for a nice lunch.
author: Mike L.

description:
RUDE  service and the food was average.
 There are so many other places in the area that is so much more superior. 
Our evening went sour. The management did nothing to help. Save your money and go somewhere else.
author: Cynthia S.

description:
Went here for a business dinner I ff a tip from the hotel.  And what a great tip it was!

We did apatizers, a pasta course, and a final course.  I had the alfredo and the filet.  Both were among the best dishes I've had in years, with the filet mignon cooked perfectly (something I've had trouble finding recently).

I should not forget to mention that the staff was friendly and helpful at all times.

I highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Jared C.

description:
Given it's somewhat pompus name, one would expect the North Beach restaurant to be the stick by which all other restraunts in this district are measured. This is unfortunate because, all in all, the "North Beach" restaurant is a  pretty damn short stick

I've been here twice, once with family which was an experience I pretty much forget, except for my distinct memory that, upon leaving the restaurant I was given the rare and wonderful opprotunity to use the word "clusterfuck".

The second time I came here I went, as usual, with my girlfriend. In all honesty, there really isn't much I have to say about this place that was postive other than that we were seated quickly and the server was knowlagable about the menu.

The bads:

The corkage fee here is pretty much rediculous, $35 dollars. Included in this fee were two short, narrow shitty glasses that allowed my $65 dollar chianti to breath like a fat, asmatic, youth in a marathon. Our waiter was excessively attentive to my wine, constatly refilling my glass as if there were some sort of bomb attached to my table that would explode if my glass had less than 3 onces of wine in it. Maybe it's just me, but after the first pour, I like to self serve.

Foodwise, we got some pruchitto thing that was decent and our server recommended but that wasn't very memorable. My girlfriend ordered something with marinara sauce that was alright, but nothing extrodinary. 

I ordered steak. I ordered steak in the only way it should be ordered, Meduim rare. Now one may argue that steak should be cooked to another temperature, perhaps rare, perhaps more cooked, but you are wrong. It's doesn't matter that it's an opinion-based discussion. If you want a well done steak, just get a burger, if you want a rare steak, go out for sushi. Thank you. 

That said my $35 steak did not come out medium rare. No blood was to be had on my plate and the middle was only slightly pink. Additionally, the outside of the steak was so burnt it was as if the chef had chosen to put the meat IN the fire rather than on the grill. The steak came with some sad looking spinach and maybe some potatoes. Fucking awful. I failed to complain to the waiter, yes totally my bad, but i didn't want to spend more time in that restaurant than i absolutely had to.

Overall the "North Beach" restraunt is a stain on this district rather than an exemplary member. The menu is boring, unimaginative, and average. The chefs are mediocre at best and the food/service doesn't match the five star price.
author: Logan H.

description: Good spot for a business dinner. Their wine was very nice. And gnocchi was excellent with the meat sauce. Maitre d was a friendly welcoming presence. But pricey for North Beach area.
author: Chris L.

description:
Dining coupons from a time share seminar brought us to North Beach.

Had it not been for the FREE food, fiance and I would of never of come here.

THREE $$$ is just too much for some Italian food!

We tried to order specialty dishes like the beef carpaccio and braised lamb.   The carpaccio was amazing!  Fresh onions, capers and lemon complimented the fresh beef well.

The rest of the food however, was just mediocre.  My lamb wasn't medium rare as requested and the vegetables that came with the dish were soggy and looked like they've been sitting out.

The ambiance of the restaurant is pretty dated and dull.  Overall there was no wow factor for me... 

To be honest, Bucca di Peppo hits closer to home! or the Stinkin Rose down the street :)
author: Earlene C.

description:
This review is mostly for Ligaya. Our beloved Boston Community Manager is moving to the Bay Area. Sooner or later, she'll hear the name of the North Beach restaurant spill from the lips of some Yelper and go in for a dip.

NBR, my dear Ligaya, is much like G'vanni's or Mama Mia in the North End. The decor is that muraled Italian-old school-bistro-cute we all know. The food, while very tasty at the basic pasta/antipasto level, is not exactly innovative. Would avoid major meat selections, esp. chicken, as they can be dry. Wine list? Scusi? Si! Great selection of Italian wines here...and for me that's really the draw. I love to order some rosso or chianti I've never heard of and gulp it down with my Tagliatelle Bolognese. 

Portions are abundant (you'll leave the restaurant needing to jettison your belt from your bulging stomach), but they slap you right in the wallet here. No entrees are below $20. Waitstaff is regrettably inconsistent; indifference abounds. 

Overall, Ligaya (and everyone else considering NBR) , I think you'd like the place somewhat, but be wary! Drop by the bar for a bottle and and antipasto, but you may not want to make it an evening. 2.9870946543267 stars.
author: Jef S.

description:
I recently organized a group dinner here for 19 people and this place had really great food and service. I worked with Bui to set up the reservation who was hilarious and totally flirting with me (I do sound hot over the phone) lol... He was super accommodating! The prosciutto room was not an appropriate room for this dinner, as this was an outing with our bosses boss visiting from out of town. Nothing says professional like a bunch of meat hanging above your head, so Bui said that we could have half of the Wine Cellar. They arranged the table so it was a huge square, which was perfect for the social outing. 

The food was awesome! I had the osso buco, which fell off the bone and reminded me of how my mom cooks it. I also tried someones' stuffed sole which was very delicate. We had a white and a red on the table at all times, and the option of sparkling vs. still water was a nice touch. We had a trio appetizer which had lobster, prosciutto and melon, and the burratta. The food was amazing and the service was exceptional. 

My only complaints are that the buratta was on a hot house tomato that was a bit short of ripe, and the greens that came with my osso buco were super bitter. Other than that, everything was copesetic! I'd go back here for their Scallops, which looked delish!
author: Brandy B.

description: I absolutely love this place! I always go here for special occasions and you can normally gets reservation last minute. Ask to sit downstairs in the wine cellar for a really cool atmosphere. The service is amazing- they always treat us like family as soon as we walk in the door. The food is amazing, some of the best Italian food in SF. I highly recommend this place!!
author: Addison M.

description: I have been coming to this restaurant since 1985 and have never been disappointed in the food or the service. Since 1985, I have been fortunate to have traveled to Italy many times and I can honestly say it is the closest to a Roman experience that you will find in San Francisco. The food is divine. The waitstaff are welcoming; truly Italian and good natured. There may be more 'hip', newer Italian fair to be had around the City, but this is the only one that transports me to Rome on each visit.
author: Kevin M.

description: I have been going here since I was a little Bambina.  Food is high quality and so is the service!   You can't go wrong coming here whether it's a first date, birthday celebration, anniversary or just casual dining.  I highly recommend it!  Grazie Lorenzo, Peter, Warren and Dino for yet another fabulous dining experience!  Molte benedizioni e buona fortuna!
author: Michelle M.

description:
Upon arrival, I greeted the maitre'd in Italian.  Immediately, he warmed up to me and when I was leaving the restaurant, he spoke Italian directly at me with a warm smile...simpatico.

we sat outside the room where they hung proscuitto from the ceiling.  I like to eat proscuitto and theirs is aged at 9 months but to eat in a room with meat hanging over your head really makes you feel you're eating in a meat locker.  I'll pass. 

Appetizers here are what you expected and tasted fine.  I was disappointed in the seafood risotto that my husband got... it wasn't creamy enough and a bit watery.  I told my husband you do a better job! 

However, I did enjoy my entree - their veal saltimbocca alla Nerone - this was delicious and is one of their signature dishes. The kids loved the linguine with clams (white version). 

Dessert - skip it.. overpriced.  I would find a gelato shop outside the restaurant. 

Service was top notch , the food was just okay - hit and misses.
author: Salena M.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. The cuisine is great and moderately priced for San Francisco. The seats are small and little elbow room between tables. As for the pasta dish I had, absolutely to die for.  Parking around here can be a big challenge.
author: May M.

description:
Food was ok.  Service pitiful.  The waiter brought a sample of wine.  He asked if we wanted more.  I was suspicious.  Glanced at the wine listed and his suggestion was $22 a glass.  Was he going to tell us before the bill showed up?  

After ordering an assortment of drinks (2 beers and 2 glasses of wine), I guess he figured we weren't going to spend enough money and the service became very unattentive.  Our water glasses remained empty throughout much of the meal.  At one point I got the water pitcher and refilled our glasses.

We did have a melon, prosciotto and burrata appetizer that was very good.  I ordered a white fish entree that was so-so.  Not bad, not great.  My husband enjoyed his scallops.  The bread was good.

One of my friends ordered a second glass of wine that never came until we reminded them again 15 minutes later.  The restaurant was almost empty, so theyre were no excuses for the poor service.  We were about to order dessert, but decided we couldn't spend another minute there.  So we left and went across the street for gelato and coffee.
author: Greta N.

description:
So when my parents come to town, I try to find new places to take them to.  This place has been around for ever and I figured why not, I've been there before and felt like Italian food.  But having been to Italy our standards run high.

We had great service from the time we showed up, the waiter was very chatty and offered some great suggestions for food and wine.  My mom had some special requests and they accomodated all of them without any obvious comments.

We had a great bottle of Pinot and some appetizers to start and then all of us got Veal.  Yes I know all about how they are treated, but they taste so great and that they did, the meat was so tender we didn't even really need a knife, the sauces were great, flavorful but not heavy or overbearing.  The meal was light and after none of us felt overly full like so many times after going out to eat.  

The location is great as well, lots to do around there and walk around.  They also have private dining rooms great for parties and groups when you want to just have some exclusivity.
author: Inga W.

description:
So, we had reservations for dinner after Beach Blanket Babylon, since no one else knew if they could commit to dinner.....
As it turned out, the 6 other people we were with wanted to do dinner.
We had printed out , (from Yelp) several highly rated restaurants nearby, but, (surprise, surprise) none of them could take a party that big, at such short notice.

This place could, although it was far from our first pick..or second...or third...

We had a feeling it would be pretty mediocre, since it's on the main North Beach strip.

They seated us in the wine cellar, which was interesting, it is a very pretty restaurant. I'll give them that but that's about all I'll give them...

Service was fairly bad. I felt pretty neglected....
It took way too long for the server to take our drink order. He asked us as soon as we sat down, (we hadn't had time to look at the wine list) and then he disappeared.

They were good about refilling waters, and bread. Although, I didn't eat much of it, it wasn't very good.

It took a very long time to give our orders, and then even longer to get them.

I wanted the seafood risotto, butwas told  it had to be done with heavy cream, or red sauce. What is up with that? Risotto DOES NOT have to have heavy cream. 
Anyway, I ended up ordering grilled halibut, with the lemon butter sauce on the side.
It came with some greasy, unappealing potatoes and sugar snap peas.
The fish was moist, but even with the sauce, it was flavorless.

Since my entree was so unsatisfying, we decided to share the chocolate mousse. 
It was actually good, but I doubt it's made in-house.Maybe that's why it was good.....

I can't recommend this place. Even though it was great they got us seated in a pinch, it just wasn't very good.
author: Amanda G.

description:
We were referred to North Beach restaurant while wine tasting at Lorenzo's (owner) winery in Sonoma. We made a reservation and when the entire party arrived we were seated immediately. After ordering some wine, which I'll get to later, a few plates of appetizers were brought to our table, unordered. We told the waiter we didn't order them but he didn't seem to care. We were unsure if we'd get charged for them but when the bill came we learned they cost about $60! A pretty hefty tab in my opinion. Overall, I found the food to be good, though I wouldn't say it was the best Italian I've ever had. 

If you're a fan of red wine, I'd suggest a glass (or bottle) of Petroni Cabernet Sauvignon. If you're more a fan of white I'd go w/ Petroni Chardonnay. (These wines come from the owner's vineyard in Sonoma, Petroni Vineyards.)
author: Kim P.

description: I'm a fan of this place. I love how extensive their menu is, and I've enjoyed everything I've ordered there. They also have valet parking, which is awfully convenient. The service is great as well. They also have an extensive wine list, and many reasonably priced wines by the glass. This can be a fun place to take out of town guests, because the atmosphere evokes old Italy and the neighborhood is fun to walk around.
author: Diana G.

description:
Stopped in here while walking in North Beach and wanting handmade pasta......
We definitely had our craving satisfied. The wait staff was pleasant and professional and the food was superb.
I had the Canelloni (house spacialty), my boyriend had the Carbonara, and the Tiramisul; all were delicious!!
author: Lauren T.

description:
3.5 stars.

I came here with a larger group for a work dinner. I have NEVER heard of this restaurant until the night I was dining there. We arrived and were seated at a large nice square table. It was cozy and our group was immersed in various conversations. 
The waiter came by and took our order for the appetizers which he went on to describe "something special just for you". Our appetizer was great though - it was plated for each person - buratta, baby lobster, and two diff types of prosciutto. The baby lobster tails were excellent! 
Our waiter came by again as we were browsing the menu for our mains. He was more than happy to give recommendations for mains and offered that he can split the pasta course for everyone so that we could sample a little. We had two different types of pasta (one meat and one with white sauce and shrimp) both were delicious and having them split out the pastas individually was a nice touch.  For my main I decided on the grilled lamb filet and my dining neighbor had the halibut in red sauce. She raved about her fish. My lamb I thought was just okay but perhaps I was too full to enjoy all of it. 
Finally for dessert we ordered a few desserts to share with our coffees and our waiter brought us a free lemonciello type of drink. It was SO DELICIOUS. Perfect for an after dinner drink or for a great sunny day. 
Overall, the food and service were good but for myself I am not sure if this is a place I would come back to.
author: Julie F.

description: I was invited to a birthday dinner held at this restaurant.  The wine and food were good.  Nothing amazing, not awful but your basic Italian fare.  However, unbeknownst to us, the wine they liberally kept pouring for us was quite expensive and they included an appetizer which I thought was part of a prix-fixe menu but was actually quite an expensive addition that no-one had requested.  They did not have the main course I ordered and instead of asking me for a replacement, they just brought me something else and put it in front of me.  And when I protested the waiter said, "We were out of what you ordered"  In the end, it was $165 per person for a meal I sort of thought was okay.  Seriously, $165 for one person?  I would have gone to Gary Danko or LaFolie for that price.
author: Virginia T.

description:
I would highly recommend North Beach Restaurant.  I held a work dinner there with 20 people before seeing Beach Blanket Babylon.  They were fantastic!  They knew we were seeing the show after dinner and had us in and out in time for the show without us feeling rushed.

The food was exceptional.  With large parties, you expect the typical pre-cooked and ready to go menu, but I was very surprised at the quality.  Our menu offered something for everyone and they even added in another dish we were not expecting.  We had folks in from Europe and they commented that is was some of the best Italian food they had in the US.

I was happy that I was able to stay under budget and there were no last minute surprises on the bill that can happen at other restaurants.  I also liked that they told us what the suggested tip was, but did not automatically add it in.  It allowed me to tip them what I felt was appropriate and more than the 15%-17% they add on.

The staff was amazing.  Our glasses were never less than 1/2 full.  They were very aware of all their guests... even in the very busy holiday season when it can easily get overwhelming for them.  The service never skipped a beat!

I can't wait to use them again and have already spread the word around the office!
author: Mary V.

description: Had the most AWESOME meal with friends. Our waiter was great. The food was incredible. I had the sea scallops, which were cooked to perfection. My friend had spaghetti carbonara. The pasta was prepared al dente and the sauce was so good. My other friend had oso bucco. The meat was so good and the sauce...delicious! I will definitely come back.
author: Lisa H.

description:
Italian Gone Astray

5 hours from my most recent meal, and starting to get a little weak in the knees, I made my way over to North Beach, an as of yet uncharted food corner of the city for me.  On my own for the evening, I thought I'd try Little Italy of the West.  A quick FourSquare search revealed on option close to where I was standing, but after a 5 minute wait in a restaurant that wasn't full, I decided to cross the street where North Beach Restaurant, with its schnazzy facade, prime location, and good crowd seemed like a next best option. 

Greeted at the door by the friendly maitre d', I was shown a nice table, and plopped my weary self down for what smelled like a promising repast. Kudos to the senior wait staff for their upkeep - its rare, particularly in this city where casual is a serious undertaking, to find a throwback where gentleman of a certain age don a black tie to serve.  

The obligatory bread plate (focaccia, french, rustic) was quickly presented, along with a much needed glass of water and the wine list.  

And it was all down hill from there.  

The tome of a wine list oddly had the 'by the glass' section on the 2nd to last page.  The hundreds of wines by the bottle under-compensated for the tired BTG selection of predictables (Pinot Grigio, Chianti, Barbara) and some odd choices (several sparkling "combos"), so I decided to wing it and go with their house Sonoma blend.  Meh.  

The laminated menu looked to have been compiled in the mid-eighties with nary a variation since.  The tired roster of done to death regulars like Veal Marsala and Chicken Parm was...I suppose...to be expected in this 'hood. I guess I half expected to find something interesting, but probably not at an establishment with all the trappings this place had.  Oh well.  Classics can be good, if they're done right.  

I ordered a small salad and the porcini risotto. 

The salad, albeit not dressed to death, was fine.  SF uses terms like local, organic, and fresh with much more aplomb than many other places in this country, so I was hoping for more than iceberg in what seemed like leftover caesar salad dressing. 

My hopes for better things forthcoming were dashed immediately upon seeing the slop that was supposed to be porcini risotto.  Without tasting it, without even stirring it, I could tell it was all wrong.  

NB: I like to order simple dishes like this when I go to a new place, because 1) they're pretty hard to get completely wrong and 2) its a good test to see that the rest of the menu has a solid foundation.  

More than risotto, it resembled rice porridge with mushrooms.  My mind went to Giorgio Locatelli's beautiful description of the 'mantecatura', that wonderful, creamy binding that elevates risotto its place higher on the menu than one would think to put a simple rice dish.  It is done as the last stage of making the dish: in the pan one vigorously whips with a wooden spoon cold cubes of butter and shredded parmigiano reggiano into the rice, using all the enthusiasm and arm power needed to whip cream by hand.  The end result is a glistening web of fat that binds the rice together.  

Here's what my dish had: undercooked, chewy rice with complimentary undercooked and tasteless porcini's in scant numbers, swimming in liquid that 10 more minutes on the stove would have greatly improved the whole dish (but only in texture).  To boot, the broth was 'delightfully' gritty.  A note to those folks who use porcini's: once you've steeped the mushrooms, you must 1) strain the liquid with very fine cheese cloth before adding it to the broth, and 2) rinse the mushrooms, as they have after all been growing in dirt.  

For $27 (!!!) I should say I reasonably expected better. 

An affront to the dish to be sure, and the stuff was so hot I burned my tongue, even after waiting a few minutes for it to cool down.  Wah wah wah. 

Suffice it to say, I did not opt for dessert, especially after watching the globs of stuff they call tiramisu that was being served at the table next to me.  

I would put no stars, but I'm not sure you can and still post a review.   I would very much like to see these types of restaurants go by the wayside forever, and I'm shocked to see this relic still doing business in a city that purports to know food.  There are far too many in existence near the old homestead, but I have seldom been as disappointed anywhere there as much as I have been here.  

I shall not make a second trip.

J Castellano

PS - I tried to redeem the whole experience by popping over to Stella's for what is supposed to be SF's best cannoli, but the two idiots making coffee (does it take two people to hit the button on the espresso machine?) were so un-attentive to the 6 people standing in line in front of me that I had to leave to spare my jangled nerves from further assault.  North Beach, you disappoint.
author: Joe C.

description:
Inconsistant food and very rushed service with an attitude.  Not fine dining ambiance as the courses were brought out one on top of another.  For my main course I had the Filet of Lamb alla Bruno with Barolo Sauce in which the lamb itself was quite good but the potatoes were barely warm and tasteless and the greens were just terrible with a weird perfumey (soapy?) after taste.  Nice wine list but again with an attitude - I had a glass of the house made Brunello which was very nice but the wine steward was rather an ass because my husband didn't want any.  
Just not an enjoyable experience in any way.   There are much better options in this lovely city and I am sorry that we wasted a meal on this disappointing venue.
author: Diane D.

description:
North Beach Restaurant was a little difficult to rate because the food really was very good, but the price was a bit high. I understand that there are gourmet Italian restaurants and you pay a premium to dine at those establishments. However, I didn't consider North Beach a gourmet restaurant, but more of classic/traditional restaurant, and as a result, the pricing seemed a bit high to me. Anyway, on to the food. We had the fried calamari and caprese salad as appetizers. The fried calamari was great, but the caprese salad was lacking a flavorful/juicy tomato, so it was a bit disappointing. I had the tagliatelle bolognese pasta and it was amazing. My Mom had the Cannelloni, which I tried, and it was also great! Their wines by the glass were pretty good, but again, a bit overpriced. 

I would eat at North Beach Restaurant again, and I would recommend it others, but with a word of caution on price. If the prices were a little lower, this would be a 4 or 4.5 star spot.
author: Nick C.

description:
Fiance and I came here for dinner last Saturday, and my only quirk was the fact that our reservation was at 8pm (we arrived 15 minutes earlier) and we didn't get seated until 8:45pm.  Yes..we waited an HOUR with reservations.  Minus 1/2 star. 

Once we were seated and handed the menus, our server didn't even go over specials with us or anything!  Although i could hear him telling the tables around us the specials for the evening.  Minus 1/2 star.  

Now let's get to food.  My fiance had the spinach and ricotta ravioli.  He loved it.  He would definitely like us to go again.  I had the mushroom rissotto.  which was nice, because it wasn't drenched with cheese or cream.  

I would definitely like to come here again and give them a higher rating, although i've got to figure out a time where it isn't so crowded and when i actually may get seated at my reservation time.
author: Brenda H.

description:
Went on a hot date here. This place has $10 valet parking, which in simple Nevada is BS, but in San Francisco is unfortunately reasonable. I just deducted it from my tip for the waiter.

The wine list is extensive, but my sweet lady and I opted for a glass of the Syrah and Zinfandel, respectively. I must say, my Zin was absolutely killer, and that's just the standard wine there. 

Assortment of bread was nice, plus the vinegar and oil was imported from Italy and that's super cool. 

I ordered the Chicken Scallopine Piccata and she oredered the Eggplant Parmisiana (more commonly known as Eggplant Parmesan here in the states). This leads me to a complaint: What's the deal with this half Italian, half English garbage they have going on in the menu. With all these fancy and therefore delicious-sounding things on the menu like "Chicken al Mattone," who is going to order "Breasts of Chicken?" Boring! Fix that. "Petti di Pollo" sounds way better.

Moving along, it was surprisingly boisterous inside. The romance was all but gone as a result. I don't tuck my shirt in to go somewhere raising my voice somewhere. I'm much less suave when I have to raise my voice.

I suspect that the waiter did not give us as much attention because we are a bit younger than the average guest. Like we weren't going to tip him or something because we were poor and/or didn't understand tipping. I have a credit card, jerk! 

But shoot, I can't give $10 to the valet and to the waiter. What am I supposed to do in this situation!?

The food was absolutely amazing. The chicken was tender and the sauce was silky smooth and exactly what I wanted. The potatoes were of a nice thickness and tasted great when dipped in the sauce. Even the vegetables were good. At most places that's like a garnish and they don't put much effort into it, but here I actually wish I had more. Good mix of spinach and artichoke with some sort of lemon zest. 

I didn't try the Eggplant because I take issue with its misleadingly unsavory name. Also, I don't like how it tastes. But apparently it was also really good.

Highly recommended based on the quality of the food and drink alone. If you don't mind a little noise, this place may very well be your favorite fine Italian dining spot in San Francisco.
author: Luchenzo D.

description:
I always stop here for lunch when in the city. I know there are a lot of Italian restaurants in the city but this is by far my favorite one. Drive up and the valet takes your car and parks it. You enter the restaurant and immediately you are made to feel that you are a very special person. Your escorted to a table and when your waiter arrives you feel like your the king of England or something. Service here is superb. What I like more than anything else is the Sand Dabs when in season. They prepare them better than anywhere else. Another thing I like here is the selection of wine they have. If you ever come here you just have to take a tour and go into the basement and check out their wine cellar. Mmmmmm nice.
Have never had a bad or mediocre meal here. Service has always been excellent. When you're done and walk out the door you give your ticket to the Valet and he gets your car, holds the door for you. Service extraordinaire with a smile. Makes you want to come back again and again.

5 thumbs up here.
author: Charlie O.

description:
I have eaten several times over the past few years and had good food and service.  This time we ate upstairs and based on the food and the service I will not eat here again.  Firstly, we ordered before-dinner drinks and a bottle of wine for dinner at our table and the waiter immediately started to hassle us to order our dinners.  It was obvious that he wanted to turn the table over as quickly as possible.  After we asked him to give us time to enjoy our drinks it was obvious he did not like this.   After this our waiter, Niño, was curt and disinterested in serving us.

The bottle of white wine was delivered without an ice bucket initially.  He did not offer to let us taste the wine before serving it.  

When he explained the specials he gave them such a muffled cursory itemization, we did not know exactly what they were.  

My sister ordered the Osso Bucco which she said was so fatty she did not eat it.  I ordered the halibut which was a nice piece of fish but was broiled to the point that it tasted charred.  The potatoes were sparse and over cooked.

In summary, this was a very disappointing meal and totally over priced for the quality of the food and the service.
author: Jane H.

description:
We found this restaurant by asking a couple of locals walking down the street. We were looking for an Italian restaurant with a nice wine list and authentic food. Upon walking in, we were greeted by one of the owners who you could tell absolutely loved his place. The restaurant was very nicely decorated and even though it was rather full, was not too loud.

The waiters were dressed in tuxes which added to the experience. He was also very helpful in helping my wife pick out a meal. The entire experience was great and I reccomend this for anyone.
author: Drew P.

description: This restaurant makes you feel welcome and has excellent service. The wait staff know the menu and do not steer you wrong. The lasagna is meaty and not too big, and the linguini with clam sauce is light and fresh. The calamari appetizer (cold not fried) is flavorful and refreshing, and if you like Caesar salad, try theirs - it is yummy. Large wine selection and full bar for regular cocktails. We visit it every time we are in town.
author: Laura G.

description: Six of us ate at the restaurant last night. The food was very good as was the service. We would definitely go again.
author: Jim S.

description: Great welcoming Italian place! The manager and our server Nino were very friendly and inviting. The Risotto Porcini was wonderful. It is now my 2nd favorite that I've ever had. My guest had the Eggplant - which was tasty, just slightly thicker than she prefers. Overall, I'd go back again. Service and food were great!
author: Lindsay H.

description: I think if there is anything to try in this place you have to try the veal chop.  The chop is moist and tender.  The chicken piccata is not dry and it has nice caper sauce.  These are professional waiters not the ones you see at TGI Friday's.  It is a very old school place.
author: Stevezee C.

description: I will never forget the amazing pasta primvavera dish I had here.  Unfortunately that was 40 years ago and I have not been back to California.  If I ever get back to California I will definitely go back to the North Beach Restaurant.  It was a fantabulous evening.  The abmience, staff, food, etc.  I am a foodie and have eaten in many restaurants in many states and have never had pasta primavera as good as the pasta primavera at the North Beach Restaurant.  I wish I could have the recipe so I could replicate it.  I recall a table of patrons nearby who were having such a wonderful time, laughing and talking.  The waiter asked what we wanted to drink and my boyfriend and I said, "We'll have whatever they are having."  It turned out to be a bottle of Bolla Bardolino!  We wound up laughing and really enjoying our evening as well.  I forgot what my boyfriend had, but I do remember that in addition to the pasta primavera everything else was delightful.  Also I remember the staff being very professional and friendly!  I hope it is still the same and that the food is as good.
author: Patricia R.

description: Fantastic dining experience this evening as our work team of nine visited the North Beach Restaurant!!  Loved the 2011 Petroni Pinot Noir.  All our entrees were perfectly prepared and the service was very attentive and personal.  Treat yourself and friends to a special meal here.
author: Lori Semeniuk S.

description: I've dined here multiple times for business and pleasure.  I get a distinct "I'm in Italy" vibe when here.  Love the decor.  Service is fantastic and accommodating.  The wait staff is attentive and although we have not ordered much (e.g. salads, apps, drinks, espresso, etc.), it's always been tasty and fresh and we've always been made to feel welcome and cared for.  Definitely warrants a return visit next time I visit the city.
author: Allan S.

description:
My work hosted our holiday party here in December, and I was really unimpressed. 

Let me just say this: North Beach Restaurant, your servers choose to treat their "private event" guests with rudeness and disrespect, and your food, quite frankly, is crap. 

My pesto pasta (recommended by a server) tasted like weed. Yes, as in marijuana, which prompted me to update my FB status with "Apparently, when you overuse basil, it DOES taste just like weed." The status was a hit; your pesto was not. 

Four of our guests ordered filet mignon, none of which were cooked right. One was ordered to be butterflied, and cooked "well done.". While the greater crime here is really ordering a piece of filet mignon "well done," that piece of steak still came out PINK. One of our salads had a piece of looong blonde hair perched neatly on tip. Obviously, we sent that shit back, and our server says, "That's weird. No one in the kitchen even has blonde hair." What a sales pitch. Perhaps you have some oceanfront property in Arizona for sale?

Most Italian places I've been to do really great desserts. This isn't one of them. The  tiramisus came out mushy and muddled, my semifreddo tasted like a wet sponge, and the cheesecake didn't even get finished. 

For these reasons alone, North Beach Restaurant is not worth going to. Since it was a work party, obviously I didn't have to pay, because if I had forked over money for this crap, I would've gone all table-flipping, Jersey Housewife mad on these folks.  We are a local business in the City, but judging by the other reviews, it seems that NBR gave us the "Tourist Treatment." Nothing like neighborly love, huh? Add on top of all of this, the horrible service, and you've got yourself one crap sundae. And I, for one, do not enjoy eating poo.
author: Sachi T.

description: We had dinner  there last night for my parents 49th anniversary. We had amazing service, delicious food, and a wonderful time. The is place to go for authentic Italian food. Our waiter (I wish I could remember his name) was so attentive and had great suggestions for our group. He helped us decide on the many different things we wanted to try, and arranged our plates for us, dividing up the appetizers so we could all try some of each. Wonderful!  I used Open Table to book the reservation, which was really easy to do online.
author: Suzy S.

description: A group of four of us had a very, enjoyable Sat. night dinner. We had four different veal dishes and all were delicious.  Good wine list with a wide range of prices.
author: Joan S.

description: Similar to other reviews . . . this place is great as a staple.  If anyone ever asks "whats a good place in North Beach" this is my go to BUT it's very traditional and in this day of inventive menus, it falls a little short.  Wonderful atmosphere.  Great wine list.
author: C W.

description: The food was fabulous. Service was great  looking forward to going back. Marsala chicken was very tender and great flavor.
author: Julie L.

description: Best Osobuco in town!! Food and service is very authentic.  Although a little pricy, I recommend the sampler appetizer before dinner.
author: Steve C.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for awhile, because I was told "it's the same as Sodini's but twice the price." Since Sodini's is pretty average, I figured whoever told me this must be biased because she just prefers Sodini's, and probably NBR was much better.

I happened to be passing by on Wednesday and my friend noticed Gavin Newsom's car parked in front (how he knows what Gavin's car looks like is a complete mystery to me), so I figured he must be celebrating his Lt Gov win. I decided to eat there because well, if it's good enough for Gavin it's good enough for me!

I guess that's not true though. :(

My friend was right, the food is the same average fare as Sodini's but twice the price. My Caesar Salad was fine, but so is the one I make at home with bottled dressing. My Veal Marsala was dreadful: sickly sweet, no taste of Marsala, tough veal. The vegetable accompaniment a lone pathetic steamed broccoli crown, at $27.

The Osso Bucco Special was much better, a rich flavorful tomato sauce, tender meat, but at $33 too much money.

The service was fine, the owner friendly and obliging, but the food is from the '60s, and if you like old school Italian, you can get better food at Marcello's or Joe's of Westlake for way less money.

The ambiance is nothing special, OK it's in North Beach, but so are a lot of other places that have better food or the same food for less.
author: Rob C.

description: This was a special occasion for my folks 50th Anniversary & even though the food was very good, they have a bit of an attitude there that was definitely a turnoff. Booey, who I think was one of the Maitre d's said he would take good care of my folks & I since it was their 50th. I bought a special bottle of wine in, which I was charged a $30 dollar corkage fee, ok that I could see with their great wine selection, but they don't do substitutes. Charged $10 dollars extra for an ordinary linguine with olive oil n garlic. Now mind you we ordered drinks at the bar as well as deserts. Nothing special was done for my folks there for their 50th, which I thought kind of sucked. The waiter we had also had no personality as well of a bit of an attitude. All I wanted was to make this a special evening for my folks since it was their 50th anniversary & it's like they could've cared less. Probably my last time ever going back to this establishment again!!
author: Dave F.

description:
Way overpriced. some food was great, some was just OK, our waiter was rude; and in fact I've just read the same thing in the other reviews.
I would NOT go back. San Francisco has ton of places with better food, prices and service!
author: Stacy H.

description:
Went her for a birthday party and it was down in the private room off of the prosciutto curing room.  (all that meat hanging in front of you can make you hungry!).  Though we had several items and all were pretty good, I think my favorite of all was my appetizer of the house made prosciutto and the melon.  Simple and it tasted amazing.  :)  

Everything else was good but in no way as memorable at the appetizer.  

But service btw was excellent.
author: Denise B.

description: So nice to be able to order dinner after 11:30pm. We went to a live theatre performance and although many restaurants appeared to be open, none would serve dinner at this hour, except North Beach Restaurant. We were kindly greeted by a couple italian men standing outside the front door , once inside, the owner and host welcomed us with open arms and seated us at the window table. The waiter offered great suggestions and service. The veal and truffle pasta reminded me of the food in Tuscany. The chianti classico wine had that same musty nuance I found while in Italy. This place was so authentic I thought I was eating near a table of mafia! Great food and warm hospitality, try it, you'll like it.
author: Debi W.

description:
I'm back in SF for a business trip, and ended up here with a group for dinner.  I really miss North Beach and the traditional Italian restaurants, which Seattle sorely lacks.  This was my first visit to North Beach Restaurant, and for the most part, it did not disappoint.  We started with a selection of appetizers which ranged from mediocre to great.  The caprese was forgettable - the mozzarella was flavorless, as was the tomato.  The house cured prosciutto however was very flavorful, especially when served with melon.  The grilled baby lobster tails were also very delicious.

As for the pasta, our group had a penne in marinara and another in carbonara, which was the better choice.  For an entree, I went old school with a chicken picatta which was solid, but rather skimpy for $23.  For a dessert, we tried the house special which included sherbet, lemon vodka, and grappa, which was a nice light end to he meal.

Overall, North Beach works well for what it is.  But price wise, I would say there are better options like Delucchi's just across the street.
author: Peter L.

description: This place has a lot of character and a lot of characters.  More importantly it has VERY good food and an amazing selection of wine.  The vibe here is classy being feeling pretentious or stuffy.  It is the kind of place you can return to over and over again because you know they will always take good care of you, and you will never, ever have a bad meal here.  Excellent quality and portions.  After dinner the other night, I will now look for the Petroni name.  Their name brand olive oil and wine were excellent.  The locally sourced burrata cheese and their own cured prosciutto are delicious.  There are a lot of places in North Beach, a lot of good places, but this is the grand dame.  Enjoy!
author: John H.

description:
The Antipasti selections were very delicious.  The cured meat on the antipasto platter make me scream for More!!,  
The marinated calamari was so tender has the right crunch and not chewy
You got to try the Penne Pasta with lobster and( I think it was a blur blanc).  The pasta sure tasted like homemade

My dinner entree was very different. I thought the duck was really dry 

Too bad it was quite noisy......but what can you say, everyone didn't seem to mind the food were yum yum good

Would definitely return
author: P C.

description:
Dinner at North Beach Restaurant was kind of forced on me. A family member decided on this place to host a little reunion with visiting cousins, so I went along with the plan. Some of the negative Yelp reviews scared the wits out of me and I kind of wanted to go somewhere a little more famous and flashy. Whatever. 

The evening was really beautiful so North Beach was really hopping, making car and foot traffic pretty congested. So it was a great relief that the restaurant had a convenient corner location and valet parking. 

While waiting for the rest of our family to arrive I had a glass of grappa at the bar. It was excellent. The bar was on the small side and pretty crowded but service was prompt and helpful. 

In the dinning room, our party had a fairly large table toward back. At this angle we were able to see the restaurants lovely decor. Somebody said it had been remodeled. Also, from our vantage point we could see the place was packed! 

The waitstaff was attentive but not pushy. I know the relative recommending NBR had the owners as clients so maybe the waiters knew to recommend but to not sell up to our party. So no one had a problem with that issue. 

Our table ordered both red and white wines. Both wines were a lovely complement to our meal. 

I had the sweetbreads,  my husband ordered the brick chicken. Both dishes were perfectly prepared. There were ten people in our party and everyone really enjoyed their meal. I'm going to guess it was because we followed the recommendation of our host who knew his way around that very large menu. 

I really enjoyed my dinner at NBR. Surprise, surprise.
author: Theresa H.

description: We had a group of 25 for a Saturday night dinner in the Proscuito Room. It was a fun, intimate room and "looked super all dressed up". We worked with a Banquet Manager and Menu and were extremely happy with the choice of dishes and the quality and quantity of the food. The service was outstanding, even seeing that the restaurant was busy, we never felt rushed by staff.  I would highly recommend North Beach Restaurant.  You can't beat it for ambiance, food, service and the convenience of valet parking. Not a single thing to complain about - only raves and that includes comments of 25 women.
author: Brenda B.

description:
Very nice TOURIST TRAP!  Food was some what authentic, but definitely geared for either the well heeled or concierge guided tourist.  I was staying at the Intercontinental and the concierge recommended this restaurant on a Sunday.  I was looking for a good cioppino and she said it was one of her favorites.

After a pricy taxicab fare, I arrived as the last seating for brunch was taken.  I ordered the cioppino at $22 and was greeted with a small bowl of a few shrimp, some clams, mussels, and, I think, a scallop.  This was definitely an appetizer size entrée rather than a full on meal.  The cioppino I had at Tadich Grill was three times (3X) the size and was a full meal in itself.  Granted it was $32 at Tadich, but it was a much better product than North Beach's.

Since I was starving when I arrived, I asked the waiter for a suggestion and he recommended the special, osso buco.  Having no choice as they were closing down, I picked it and polished off another mini-entrée.  Not wanting to go to the bother of paying an outrageous amount for desert and coffee, I paid my bill and looked for a bakery instead.
author: Russel Y.

description: Food was terrible. Service was even worse. In fact, when our bill was being delivered, the waiter told us "to be quiet". We were just having conversation...on new years eve. Awful! And it was my birthday so that just made my night even worse. I would never recommend this place to anyone!
author: Rona R.

description:
Pros: Extensive menu, Decent wine list, Polite wait staff, Quiet ambience in a busy part of North beach.

Cons: Feels old, extensive menu, Nothing in the menu that's a stand out feature. 

This is a good place for the nostalgic older generation. 
The younger people will probably prefer a modern seating and ambience. 
bar that has a side view of the street.
author: V P.

description:
Visiting San Francisco with  my husbands family and asked a local Italian resident were to go for an authentic Italian restaurant and the answer was ---North Beach Restaurant!!

We were here on a party of 8 for a special occasion so we were ready to splurge a little and order many items recommended by Lorenzo, the owner:  homemade mozzarela and prosciutto were the appetizers choice.  He suggested to get one per person but in a way that I thought he was going to divide it for us so it turned out  we spent more on appetizers than on the main dishes as we order one appetizer per person.  The good thing was that he was right, their were delicious!  The fresh mozzarela was so soft it reminded a little bit of burrata with that almost creamy center.  

For main dish my favorite was the veal cannelloni , apparently veal is their specialty here.  

Would definitely come back and be more careful ordering items and actually looking at prices on menu instead of just agreeing with waiter suggestions, the bill can easily add up here!  

I recommend getting a reservation, this place is very popular
author: Daniela J.

description: Chicken Picata, was very good.  The sauce and coating for the chicken was memorably different.  There was a hint of Dijon mustard in the sauce which I would never put but it actually worked pretty well.  The side dishes were very good.  Now, the bad part was the Caesar. Too anchoveeeee. Not enough garlic or parm cheese and I guess that some folks like their Cesar's like this but I don't.  I think that garlic should be the predominant taste, not anchovy and this salad was quite fishy smelling and just did not have the nutty, garlicky taste that I prefer.  My colleague had veal Marsala which was nicely done and served with the same sides.  I have not eaten here since 2008 but this place was very good.  I just would not recommend the Cesar, based on my personal taste preferences.  However, most Cesar aficionados that I know prefer garlic and Parmesan as the main tastes, not anchovy.
author: Greg G.

description:
This was our best meal during our 2 day stay in SF. We were seated downstairs in the cellar, (ladies, bring a sweater or coat if you are dining down there) and it was quite lovely.
My kids are adventurous eaters and they were delighted to see Escargot on the menu. They decided to try it and we permitted because of its slender $11 price tag. They loved and devoroured those nasty little things. Everything we ordered was outstanding, the service was a bit pompous, but I attribute that to, well in an effort to remain politically correct, I better not say.
author: Gianna E.

description: A conundrum: The couple times I've been to North Beach Restaurant have been fraught with abysmally overcooked proteins and HUGE bills, that is until I finally tried their Sweetbreads which (surprise) are worth 5 stars on their own.  This is not an exaggeration, these Sweetbreads in all their rich, gravy-esque glory will make you want to give up oxygen.  One dish doesn't make a restaurant though, and the law of averages is cold but fair.
author: Michael D.

description:
Always, always a favorite of mine. 


And Dog friendly 

Closed my eyes and had my driver (my Husband) take me over that very high bridge. My Daughter seems to think this is humorous. My fear of heights is NOT FUNNY dearest daughter. 

We sat outside and enjoyed my favorite Antipasti. 
Toscano for Two - Home-Cured Prosciutto, Salame, Cheese, Marinated Calamari, Veal Shank, Beans and Salsa Verde. -The salsa Verde is a pesto. Oh God is this Antipasti good.... 
Followed by Veal Marsala, which was way to sweet. I should have gone with my usual Braised Rabbit. 
Daughter had the same, Mr. H. had the Veal sweetbreads. He loved it. 

I gave in, because it was my Birthday, and had a wonderful glass of wine. I really need to loosen up with that. It was so good. 

People watching on this corner is so entertaining especially on Gay Pride, Parade Day There are some great bodies out there. 
I'm old not blind. :) 
My Daughter and I giggled (everyone needs someone to act goofy with) at some of the very interesting cloths or lack there of. Even my dog looked a bit confused. 

Valet Parking is the best here. They call the Valet when you 
are presented with your check. Your car arrives, no waiting. Is that cool or what. They even held it there while we crossed the street for a Gelato. 

The service here is meticulous, 

If you haven't tried The North Beach Restaurant, give it a try. It's another Classic and I know you will love it.
author: Betty H.

description: It has been a few times that I have eaten in this restaurant. Food has been okay for me. Food has constantly been improving since my previous visits. Service has always been good.
author: John M.

description:
Party of 2 @ 8:20 on 6/12

Nice artwork on the walls-- Lots of Miros

Pretty expensive for what's served. $20 for a nearly meatless and cheeseless lasagna. Spaghetti with (tiny) bay shrimp for $23? Maybe 1oz of shrimp.

Similarly- 2 slices of tomato and mozz for $17? Pretty insulting

Lot's of better values in the neighborhood.
author: Art V.

description:
Oh Yes, Yes! Fantastic food - the zabaglione in particular was divine. I am VERY fussy about pasta, and I had the pasta sampler which was delicious. Calamari was perfectly done, only could have done with a bit more salt. The Prawns were fabulous, as was the appetizer tasting plate. 
I will definitely be back for more!
Service was charming and attentive, and the wines we ordered we particularly lush and lovely. I hear the waiters have all worked at the restaurant for years, and it shows in the pride they take in their work. The place has a lovely traditional Italian feel with really great food, I highly recommend.
author: Koshika S.

description:
My friend and I were looking for a nice Italian restaurant to have dessert (tiramisu).  It seemed like a simple thing to do.  So we ventured into North Beach, and it happened to be a Monday night.

We found North Beach Restaurant which was well-lit and well attended.  Both good signs.  People were laughing, waving their arms, and they seemed comfortable in this space.

Although dinner was out of the question, we allowed our waiter to talk us into splitting an appetizer: prosciutto, melon, and the "real mozarella."  He made it a point of calling it something else, and I forgot what the specially-prepared cheese was called (something that started with a b).  That appetizer was yummy.  Pricey, but yummy.

We were really waiting for the tiramisu.  When it came out, we noticed tha it was leaning.  Strange, but nothing to be concerned about.

Then we bit into the tiramisu.  It had been defrosting, and the icicles were melting in my mouth. Not such a good sensation.  This is why, even with the friendly staff, I can't give this much higher than 3 stars.  Good try North Beach Restaurant. Maybe another time.
author: e a.

description:
Went here for dinner with my dad last night, and forgot it was north beach festival...oops my bad!  The restaurant was filled with the trashed and hungry. Service was a little bit odd in that it was so loud, and the screaming drunks made it a bit harder for the waiters and waitresses. 

I got the minestrone, and the chicken fettucine alfredo, and wow it was all really delicious.. Really flavourful. 

My dad was really satisfied with dinner as he's really picky about italian food (he's 100% irish, i dont get it...) so I consider this dinner a success.

The best part was yelling at my dad so he could hear me, and everyone sitting around me could hear about how I got arrested, how I was doing in school, and about smoking weed. Oh did I mention my dad is deaf in one ear? It was great.

I had a good time here , and I'm looking forward to heating my leftovers...now!
author: Lauren S.

description:
The North Beach Restaurant in San Francisco is probably THE WORST restaurant that I have ever been to.  I asked for a table for two, but ended up getting a long table that was big enough to seat about 6-8 people, located in a corner of the basement by a fire exit.

Not only was the atmosphere horrible, but I've had TV dinners that had more flavor than the garbage they were serving.  The waiter was m.i.a. the entire evening, and on top of that, when I mentioned to the maitre'd how unhappy the experience was, he said "why didn't you complain sooner" and then dismissed me!!!  He just turned his back and started talking to someone else.  How rude is that???  The maitre 'd's behavior was the icing on the cake.

What a horrendous experience and horrible food.  I say stay away from this hole in the wall!
author: Jeff C.

description:
A nice truly Italian restaurant that typifies what one expects in North Beach (or Little Italy NYC, or North End Boston).  Food is average as are the prices.  What makes this place very, very special is the exceptional, professional service and the ambiance we experienced by being seated in a little alcove with our very own window.  Mentally, we had been transported to Rome or Venice!  

Thank You!!
author: Judy B.

description:
On October 20 my wife made reservation for five at the North Beach Restaurant for 7:30p through Open Table - she did this around 7:10p. Our friends were from out-of-town and were celebrating the wife's completion of the Nike Marathon and we suggested that we go to the North Beach. Unfortunately, our friend began having such bad cramps that we realized that we weren't going to dinner anywhere, so at 7:25 we tried to cancel the reservation through Open Table but couldn't with only five minutes remaining before the reservation time. Instead, I got on the phone and called to be sure that they knew we couldn't make it. I told the person who answered my name several times, but he didn't seem to understand (or want to hear) and kept repeating back a very different name. He then became angry with me and said that I had made a 6:00 pm reservation and had called to change it to 7:30, and was now calling to cancel.

 I insisted that that wasn't the correct name and said that we just made the reservations only moments earlier and wanted to be courteous and be sure they knew. He continued to blow up at me and told me how wrong it was of me to treat them that way (as I continued to protest that he had the wrong party) and said that they didn't need reservations from people like us and rudely hung up the phone. 

My wife and I have been going to the North Beach since our first visit to SF together in 1985, and have continued to go there even after the Brass 'n Glass remodel.  We have lived in the East Bay since 1995 and have gone to the North Beach several times per year and have sent many people there through the years. I would sometimes drop in by myself for the house pasta and a glass of wine. I know the person who answered thought he was talking with someone else, but the reaction was so rude and angry that it has really changed my impression of the place. As much as a love the food - and will miss the house past - I'm not sure that I'll return anytime soon. Too bad, I guess some places just run their course.
author: Gary S.

description: My girlfriend and I popped in here for lunch after walking around checking out all the menus of the surrounding restaurants. This place looks expensive, but the lunch prices are very reasonable. I had the Pasta Della Casa - Prosciutto, Mushrooms and Veal with Chardonnay Wine. It was awesome. My girlfriend had the Pasta Arrabbiata. She really enjoyed her dish too, it had a nice spicy kick to it.
author: Tim W.

description: I was in SF for the weekend and have been to the restaurant a few times but many years ago.  The food is still very good.  The service was excellent.  I read some reviews that the waiter forced an order on them, but I didn't have that experience at all!
author: Chris J.

description:
The valet parking for $10 lured us in. We didn't  even know the name of the place we were going to, but just pulled over at the nearest valet.  We gave up looking for parking after driving around North Beach for 30 minutes and avoiding the way- to- eager cops who were everywhere, giving out tickets like candy in this economy.  Into North beach restaurant we went. 

Immediately we were greeted by two older Italian men in suits who are friendly and old school   Yes!, I am in little Italy, or North Beach as it is known here. It was 10:30 on a Friday night, the place was lively and an open table awaited us. Perfect. Then, as is always the case in North Beach, the handsome Italian waiter (this time in tux) comes over, greets us, and you know it is going to be a fabulous meal. 

We could not have asked for better service thanks to Dino, our waiter. He immediately set the tone for a comfortable, relaxed and unhurried dinner. I liked being handed the small bottles of oil and vinegar, served   with bread.  I am not sure why, but this small touch helped to make the beginning of the meal relaxed and as if we were in a small Italian restaurant with the locals. And in fact we were amongst many locals, but the place isn't small, although it feels like it. Most restaurants pour the oil for you, but this felt right, having an actual bottle of authentic imported oil to pour for myself. The wine was superb and the appetizer of Romaine with Shrimp and its' homemade mayonnaise was delicious.

My husband cannot eat dairy products and this can sometimes be a problem when ordering. After  discussing the menu with us, Dino, finally took the menu out of my husbands hands and said that he would surprise my husband with a pasta dish made especially for him. He knew the chef could create a dish.  Such service was unexpected and welcome.  As`we waited for our food, sipping our full bodied wines and nibbling on bread with plenty of heart healthy olive oil, (more is better for your heart?) the older gentlemen who greeted us chatted occasionally.  Watching the groups of diners was interesting and fun. From the rowdy and inebriated table of thirty-somethings, to the lively and also inebriated table of heavyset Italian men wearing gold chains and also wearing their napkins, to the couples talking softly, this place was entertaining and lively at 11pm. 

The main course arrived of seafood risotto and a pasta dish of veal and the North Beach specialty, prosciutto, served with pappardelle pasta. Flavorful and perfectly prepared. There was no skimping on the seafood in the risotto, it was creamy and with texture, and it was what a seafood risotto should be. My hubbies' dish was very good with plenty of flavor even without any cheese. No room for dessert, we opted for a plate of small biscottis and espresso. 

Noticing people walking through the restaurant and heading downstairs to a wine cellar, I was curious and wanted to check this out. It was now midnight, and we asked if we could wander down there. Dino said he would join us, since he was finishing up. Downstairs is another dining room set in a wine cellar atmosphere. everyone had left so we wandered around and I wandered right into a room filled with hanging meats that are slowly becoming prosciutto.  If I wasn't sold on all the authentic Italianate-ness before, this sealed the deal. It doesn't get any more Italian than a room full of curing meats beside a wine cellar. North Beach Restaurant, don't change. Your food is delicious, your waitstaff wonderful, your patrons are entertaining and your truly authentic prosciutto, made in an old world style is  unique. We left happy and satisfied as North Beach was slowly winding down. Thanks to a $10 valet parking sign on the street, we found a new place to love.
author: Marilyn Y.

description: Best cannelloni EVER. Seriously. I licked the plate (almost). Great service. Great food. Love North Beach restaurants and this is one of the best.
author: Claudia S.

description: We had a large party and they literally set us up in what looked like the hallway. Very disappointing. food mediocre, didn't offer us fresh pepper with our salads and when we asked they only offered pepper to who initially asked. Did not put our Sparkling wine on ice. I will never go back.
author: Leigh M.

description:
It's true, this restaurant has seen better days. I once loved the quality of food, ambience and unparalleled level of service. A real old-school type of place, expensive but worth it- formerly.
Our server did not understand wine. For a $45 bottle that I inquired about he ought to be able to tell me something that isn't already printed on the menu. Fortunately I know a fair bit about wine and usually manage to make good selections.
 The waiter brought our wine while we were still drinking a pre-dinner cocktail (we'd been told there was a long wait). He opened it and served it to us; we hadn't any food yet, just pre-dinner drinks (which were subpar, but $$). But for a waiter to serve wine to us right then..Who does that?
