He seemed more focused on up-selling rather than helping us have the best food/ an enjoyable experience dining out. I missed the old-school waiter we used to get. Now, that guy knew about service.
The food wasn't bad, but it wasn't GREAT either. Their featured special app was burrata cheese with tomato, and basil. YUM, my favorite! We got 2 unevenly sized anemic slices of Beefsteak tomato with One basil leaf, some of that awesome cheese and a smattering of balsamic/ olive oil. The waiter was even stingy with the drizzle of the fancy olive oil.
The day before I had better tomatoes on a sandwich in a pub (seriously folks, try the chicken sandwich at the Cheiftan on Howard).
Entrees were kind of bland, over-salted and heavy on the butter/oil. My prawns were overcooked slightly, the veal left a lot to be desired..
 
An unenthusiastic/ un-knowledgeable server, no longer excellent food & $$$ made me frustrated/sad. North Beach Restaurant used to be So good- an impressive choice for special occasions. It has seriously gone downhill. I really, really was hoping this was a passing trend-- and gave them 3 chances in the last 2.5 years. They disappointed this time again.

Third time's a charm. Never again.
author: Rachel D.

description:
Picked the place at the last minute while up on business in the city.   Hotel Concierge suggested the place and seeing all of the reviews here, its clearly a place for out of town business/tourists.   I wouldn't have picked this place had my blackberry yelp app worked!!       I guess I need that Android! 

Having said that the place was very adequate for its purpose for non-locals who want a good North Beach Italian experience.    Its a safe choice.   The service was excellent, the ambiance was great especially with the abundance of Italian being spoken, and the food passable if not memorable.     

Comments/Suggestion:
Please update the menu's.    We simply ignored them and spoke to the waiter - we ordered nothing on the menu -- daily specials all around and we all enjoyed them.

Best Stuff
1.  Antipasti -- the caprese salad, melon and prociutto were excellent
2.  Vertically Integrated Food Stuff:   Their special Olive Oil and Sonoma Brunello were worth it.   
3.  Lamb Chops - I've had better but these were excellent.

There are so many great places in SF, the 3 rating is probably generous but in most other cities it would be a 4.
author: Dave M.

description:
Wow, we were surprisingly disappointed. My wife and I have on occasion sat out front and had appetizers and drinks, always enjoying it, telling ourselves "we'll have to eat dinner here sometime".  So last night was it, and sadly, we were very disappointed.  Seeing all of the 4 and 5 stars on Yelp - lots of dressed up people coming in and out sure led you to believe that this was a very nice place.  Okay enough of the story here's our rating.
Greeting - very nice, accommodating and made you feel welcome
Service - good, not great, but not a major issue.  
Food - And this was the real disappointment - I love Veal Saltimbocca, I've had it all over North Beach and it was simply cosi cosi, I've had much better.  My wife asked the waiter "what's the best thing on the menu".   With a bit of excitement, he described the sole and even said it was "divine"!  It was flowered and fried with no special sauce - it could not have been more basic.  Devine???  The high point was the tiramisu - It was awesome - the best we've had since Jovenello's (which they called Piato Forte) which hands down was the best (but now I'm dating myself).  
I'm assuming the novelty to this place is the fact that it is one of the last 3 or 4 places in NB that has that 'dress up special occasion' feel to it - but really it's just not worth it. There are much nicer/better options. We won't go back for dinner.  Sit outside on a nice early evening for drinks and appetizers or after a show go by for some tiramisu, yes, but that'll be it for us.
author: Jake A.

description:
What a shockingly awful experience we had at this so-called San Francisco "treasure."  My nephew was visiting me and getting the full Bay Area experience for the first time.  He wanted to experience a "traditional" Italian meal at one of San Francisco's North Beach established restaurants, so he, one of my girlfriends, and I, chose North Beach Restuarant.   

Our server was wonderful, but unfortunately his opportunity to serve us ended abruptly when bread and appetizers arrived.  The bread was old, stale, or I don't know what to think, AND...there was even a piece of lint in it!!  Then the burrata was as hard as regular mozzarella, maybe even harder...I could literally pick up the entire blob up with my fork like it was a piece of steak.  And the tomatoes on which the burrata was served, were mushy and old.

When I proceeded to express our concerns, the manager, who has probably been there as long as the restaurant, was rude, curt, and suggested that we should probably leave if we are displeased vs. conceding to our complaints (the evidence was right infront of him on the table) and trying to fix the errors.  We were mortified and shocked at his response...so arrogant, combative, rude, and apathetic to what were clearly restaurant errors.  What's worse, as a doting aunt, I am not ok that my nephew had to see this when the entire point of going here was for him to have an outstanding and fun dining experience. 

A couple weeks later, I called the restaurant to share about our experience, hoping that this manager (unfortunately, I got the same arrogant jerk on the phone) would want to make good on this and that maybe he was just having a bad day the day we were there.  Unfortunately, he shared that he remembered us and proceeded to scream and yell AT ME, as though I was the one her served HIM bad food, and again refused to make good on this experience and kept yelling at me.  

I guess for me, it is incredible that a restaurant that has been around so long and a manager that clearly has been there for decades, would treat guests with such disrespect and animosity.  This man's arrogance and rudeness were staggering to me, as I can't imagine that he treats all paying customers so rudely and with so much contempt when REASONABLE AND LEGITIMATE complaints are made.  Then again, in all fairness, it might just be this manager and not North Beach Restaurant...but it is a waste of time to speculate and he is the face of the restaurant to us at this point.

Fortunately, this story has a very happy ending!  We did end up going to another North Beach Italian eating institution, Fior D'Italia, and had an outstanding dining experience.  My nephew finally go the traditional North Beach SF Italian dining experience he wanted.  If things didn't go so terribly wrong at North Beach Restaurant, we never would have had the good fortune of going here.  The service and quality of the food were outstanding.  For a major tourist stop, I was very pleasantly surprised at how great the food was and my nephew LOVED his gnocchi.  I speak from experience, as I am from an Italian family with a wonderful eating and cooking tradition.  This place knows what it is doing in my humble opinion.  From the bread to the apps to the delicious fresh pasta and perfectly prepared fish and veg, we felt that the experience ended just as it should have.  Since I am a local to the SF Bay Area and never go to "touristy" places, I have to thank North Beach Restaurant for being the reason that we found Fior D'Italia....it's a little off the beaten path in North Beach and well worth the walk.  I look forward to going there again very soon to repeat that wonderful dining experience!  :-)  Thank you North Beach Restaurant!
author: Susan F.

description: I came here last Friday and really enjoyed my meal. I had some fantastic Veal cutlet Parmigiana, and my partner in crime had a tasty, although a little rich, lasagna. Both meals were good, although A LITTLE pricey - with tip, two meals, 5 drinks and a split salad, it was 140 not outrageous in the least, but date night in SF with a nice meal, a fun waiter, and not being rushed out of our table, it was worth it.
author: Sam A.

description:
Well first of all let me say hello to all my fellow yelpers out there and to all my friends. Have been gone for a while to visit some relatives in the mid-west. Tons of snow.

Well first night back had to go and have some good italian food. They just don't have it in the mid-west.

So this is where I chose to go, because they have great food, great service, great prices and most of all an excellent wine cellar, YUM.

Damn, sure is nice to be home.
author: BL T.

description:
I can't believe I spent 40$ on a bowl of hastily put together noodles slapped with bitter tomato sauce with too much garlic and a glass of white wine --- for LUNCH.  My cousin's cioppino wasn't any better...How about  a meager bowl with one clam, one shrimp, and one mussel for a whopping 21.95? It was okay, better than my meal. 

Seriously, both meals tasted like they were nuked by the microwave.

Service? Bleh. Our waiter warmed up to us, but at first was very snotty. 

To sum it up, overpriced, ALMOST mediocre Italian food. The additional star was because there was a nice seat out front. I guess the ambiance was okay, since it was a nice warm day and we got to people watch.
author: zeestacers M.

description:
Food pretty good, prices completely outrageous. 4 of us for lunch yesterday (no dessert)... we literally checked the bill 3x before paying b/c it was $179.xx before tip. Let me repeat: it was LUNCH, it was BEFORE tip, it was almost 1-8-0! 

Split app for 4 = $50. Yes, $50. Each of us got 1 single slice prosciutto w/ 1 sloppily cut pc of melon (I have no tolerance for sloppy knife work) and ~1T burrata (though they claim it was 1/2 - yeah, right) atop a small tomato slice + basil leaf + drizzle balsamic. The prosciutto & burrata were each really good, but seriously, this is a $4 app for which they charged $12.50/ea. Unbelievable... if we knew how much it'd be, no grazi, would never have happened.

Veal parm = 8/10, veal piccata & chicken piccata = 7/10, spaghetti w/ vodka = 8/10. 

Pluses: location (outdoor seating = Fido can join), valet parking (at $8, it's the restaurant's best deal), FOB Italian server, food itself.
author: Jen H.

description: Not a big fan of Italian food, but everything we ordered was great. Burrata was fresh and tasty, pasta arrabiata flavored to perfection, pasta well cooked, and the trout was off the hook. Tiramisu was soft, tasty and had some good amount of liquor in it, just a way it should be. What I also appreciated a lot was the service, Was fast, prompt, and when we ordered 2 glasses of the red house wine ( made by the owner) and I realized I made a mistake ( just do not like red...) my friend asked if it was ok to take it back and the waiter said: "Everything is ok, Sir" . Than I got a nice Pinot Grigio , which was yummy. Unfortunately I forgot to take pictures this time.
author: Agnes K.

description: We were looking for good authentic Italian. We found it! The atmosphere was very " old world" Italy. The waiter was classic. The wine choices were extensive. Veal was amazing! We had a great experience.
author: Deanna B.

description:
It wasn't hard to get reservation for a Saturday dinner and the place didn't seem to be busy at all. 

They had a big menu so it wasn't a problem to find something we liked. Bf had his always favorite Pasta Della Casa and he remembered it was just the same as that of many years ago. I tried their Pappardelle Cardinale - alla vodka with Bay Shrimp. Loved their sauce but didn't get drunk! The only thing was the huge portion. Half would be enough for me! 

We had their tiramisu and it was of a lot of rum! 

Service was nice and atmosphere was great. It was a place for tourists but also bay area locals.
author: Ile F.

description: i can't complain about the food, but I do not like the chauvenistic b.s. this restaurant hypes. We were two females and were escorted to the back room next to a family with a screaming toddler while the next couple, a man and woman were seated at the table by the window away from the family of five with the toddler. Our waiter was attentive, but the bread was slightly hard, possibly stale. The prices are outrageous for the quality of the food. The ladies room was not as clean as it should have been. $7.50 for a bottle of faux San Pelligrino. Will likely not return or recommend.
author: Eileen M.

description:
Don't let the tuxedo intimidate you, you can wear jeans here. 

The service was professional and 5 star. Wine list impressive. Food and bread were very good.
author: Ginger P.

description:
Not gonna lie, I feel like this is a tourist trap.  As a lover of Italian food, this was simply not it.  After being recommend to come here from an local I was very exited to try it, yet after the experience I could not understand why this place was recommend on the first hand.  The one good thing was that our server was Italian and he was pretty cool to talk to.  

Beginning with our appetizer, we started out with a caprese with burrata cheese.  Now, if you have read my other reviews you know how much I like buratta and the buratta at North Beach Restaurant did not even come close to measuring up to it.  That was the first sad part.  The second sad part was that my "fresh" pasta did not taste all that fresh.  I ordered a mushroom pasta and the flavors were good, but nothing memorable.  My friend ordered the chicken Parmesan and the taste was totally off.  Maybe they were have an extremely off day.  After our disappointing meal, we didn't even order dessert, something that I love.

So needless to say, I don't think ill revisit this place.
author: Cara D.

description:
Our whole family loves Italian food and part of the exploring Little Italy (North Beach) is to explore every restaurant. 

Background: it's surprisingly huge. Valet parking is in the front. Very nice fun "Soprano" style atmosphere. It's a little loud for romantic dinner for 2, but very family friendly (just try not to bring the kids, the dishes are expensive!) We were seated in the downstairs wine cellar converted to more dinner area. I love the feel of it makes me forget the busy City. 

4 stars: 
1) kind service 
2) large menu. many mouth watering dishes - veal too. Makes me want to try them all. 
3) great authentic Italian food/pasta. We ordered the linguine with mushroom and scallops, pesto gnocchi & carppacio w/capers for appetizer. The linguine was my favorite dish. The mushrooms were super flavorful & the scallops were large sea scallops (no baby scallops here) The gnocchi & carpaccio were homemade, great texture, just that the pesto sauce was a little boring but still authentic. 

2 negative stars? 
1) pricey! 3 of us with 4 dishes was $122 (without dessert). 
2) the portion is not that big. The size of a $18.50 entree looks like it should cost about $12. Though I enjoyed my food, I will continue to explore cheaper options.
author: Yum Y U M.

description: I guess there must be a dress code that we were not aware of before making the reservation.  They took us down to the "dungeon" at a table far from everyone.  Not that we were poorly dressed, just casual.  Ordered drinks and after perusing the menu and not even given bread - we paid the bill and high-tailed it out of there.  The prices were a bit steep and we thought we might share plates, but those we saw were mighty small.  So in all honesty I can only review my cocktail - a cosmo - which was teeny, weeny - not only in size, but ingredients.  If they put any vodka in it, it was a drop or two.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
This is the kind of food I grew up eating that made me so fond of Italian cuisine.  Unlike that stuff you get at that restaurant on California with the yelp envy owner.

Lorenzo, the owner of North Beach Restaurant isn't on the computer in the middle of the night worrying about one star yelp reviews.   I wonder if Lorenzo has a computer?   

Someone very close to me recommended this establishment to me.  

I love ravioli from eating way too many cans of Chef Boyardee in my past.  Guys like me who grew up in the islands enjoy canned food like vienna sausage and of course, the Hawaiian steak-  spam.   I opted for the ravioli toscana my maiden visit to North Beach.  

It was wonderful!   Very rich and tasty!   And the raviolis are homemade.

Marilyn the bartender is stellar.   I like sitting at the bar to dine, therefore a professional bartender is essential to an old guy like me.   

They get their bread from Danilo Bakery a half block up on Green.  And they make the focaccia in house.  

They do have fresh pepper at the restaurant that is dispensed out of one of those electric jobs.   I believe they sell the electric pepper dispenser at the restaurant.

Lorenzo sells his own wine at North Beach from Petroni Vineyards which is his last name.    Plus, his olive oil under the Petroni label is fantastic!  

I was given a tour of the prosciutto they cure in the basement.   Then, I had to try an order.   It's simply incredible!  The best prosciutto I've ever had, not too salty.   

A good way to finish a meal is to sample a scorpino.   It's like an icee.  North Beach has two dispensers- one which is lemon and the other an unspecified burgundy color.

My best meal thus far in my extended visit to the Bay Area.

And no 4% surcharge to mangia...
author: Randal P.

description:
For the longest time my family did not go to North Beach Restaurant, Once about 5 or 10 years ago we had a run in with a RUDE Maitre D and said "That's it!" but for some reason we went there for my momma's birthday this year, and I am GLAD we did.  What a DELICIOUS restaurant!n  I am a sucker for a good gnocchi and they do it with gorgonzola and I LOVE it.  We also went back later with my uncle and aunt and had an AMAZING motzerella that was like butter and prosciutto, I never even LIKED prosciutto until I tasted this one.  

A little, OK more then a little pricey, particularly if you get wine, but well worth it for a special occasion.
author: Amy P.

description: We had dinner a few weeks ago for 6 people--We have been there many times and found the food about a B average with high prices. We had a bad experience on the corkage fee$30. For a few years the restaurant had waved the corkage fee if a customer brought in Petroni Wines the former owner's  winery. At dinner after Lorenzo's the owner's passing we were told no waver of corkage fee. When I questioned the change in policy--someone from the restaurant who indicated via email that they have been with the restaurant over 40 years and knows of no such policy ? So I guess over the past few years I was IMAGINING IT ! After this treatment--I don't think we will be going back to the North Beach Restaurant for some time. Too bad Lorenzo has passed on he was the heart and soul of the restaurant.
author: Bill H.

description:
After tons of searching where to eat before Beach Blanket Babylon I was discouraged with the wide array of opinions of the close by restaurants.  I finally gave up trying to decide based on reviews and we just went to the place my friend's husband likes to go... North Beach Restaurant.

We arrived about 6pm on a Saturday without a reservation & after a very brief wait we were seated at a nice table close enough to a window.  The Maître d' was really nice, oddly flirty with my friend, and was very helpful with helping us pick wine.  

The house made Brunello de Sonoma / Rosso de Sonoma (I think theses are the names) were both good with the food.  And really for the price the Rosso was just fine if eating.  Brunello maybe just by itself.  Though I'm no wine expert by any means.  Just looking at the $22 a glass price tag.

As for the food, we liked it.  Not the most shi-shi gourmet, but it had a nice homemade quality, was hearty and nicely seasoned.   The portions are pretty large.  

Started with the crab stuffed artichoke hearts.  Very good.  The caesar salad was just ok in comparison to the one we had at lunch at the Tadich Grill.  Then we shared the Polenta Soup.  We LOVED the polenta soup.  In fact, I'd love to find the recipe to try and make it at home in San Diego.  We just couldn't stop eating it although we were getting pretty full.  We finished with the chocolate tower.  Good, semi-sweet chocolate mouse definitely satisfies a sweet tooth and a chocolate craving.  I've had better, but really, it was solid.

The best part of the night was that we were there for 2 hours and never felt rushed.  We weren't in a hurry and they just let us be, yet we never felt abandoned.  I could see if a table was in a hurry this style of service might not work for them, but it worked for us.

Very happy and a very easy place to walk (around the corner) to BBB.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
The freshly home made ravioli with the simple cream sauce and the risotto with mushrooms were delicious !

Some people here complain that it is expensive - it is not cheap, but I am happy to pay a bit more for really good food - if you want cheap, look elsewhere, but if you want truly itialian food, freshly made, then come here, you won't be disappointed.
author: Tomi S.

description:
Everything is a la carte now.  

North Beach was a ghost town this Friday night.  We walked into the restaurant and were seated immediately.  

After an evening of discovering that many of the the old bars and restaurants are gone, North Beach Cafe showed up as open and alive. 

But the character has changed. All is a la carte. I ordered escargot and minestrone (avoiding consomme, per the waiter's advice), and she ordered the sweetbreads.  I enjoyed the minestrone, but she felt the sweetbreads were a little too bland, even for her Russian palate.   

Chocolate mousse, tiramisu and coffee for dessert.  The whole meal cost $74 + tip.  A dollar certainly isn't what it used to be, nor is this restaurant.  I wouldn't recommend it to tourists.  

But it was a sweet scene, and I'd recommend it for a casual evening. I love the attentiveness of the waitstaff!  

---------------
P.S. in his first Chronicle article this week, Willie Brown mentioned eating here.  
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/07/20/BAD511PR2F.DTL&hw=willie+brown&sn=004&sc=363
author: David D.

description: Had a half bottle of wine and some fresh burata cheese with tomato.  Both were good.  Place seemed a little stuffy.  I looked at the menu which was big and didn't t notice anything too special or a focus on local and fresh items.  The wait staff was all in tuxedos which seemed a little over the top.  The whole street is loaded with what I would call tourist traps focusing on Italian  cuisine, but if your looking for that type of stuff then this is the area for you.  The bottle of wine and cheese were perfect at the time.
author: Duke B.

description: Food and service were great! Very accommodating for special requests. Only criticism is it took a really long time to get our bill, we had to ask three times.
author: Heidi C.

description:
Old school like polio. But as satisfying as screwing an experienced cougar.

Go here when you want a fine plate of pasta (one of the only places I can think of in the city where you can count on just about every traditional recipe that you suddenly get a craving for actually being on the menu), a great bottle of wine and when you're feeling particularly flush in the wallet and just don't give a fuck! 

Go ahead, tuck your napkin into your shirt, talk as though your larynx were missing, and enjoy the flurry  of "pregos" and "grazies" that will make you and your date feel as though you've just stepped into a romantic teamsters banquet for two.

Don't be surprised if you find Jimmy Hoffa stuck to the underside of your table.
author: Brian S.

description:
I wish I could give this place a negative star.  My brother and his wife were in town to celebrate his birthday.  I had been told to go to North Beach because it was a colleague's favorite restaurant, so I took them there.  I can honestly say this was my worst experience at any restaurant EVER.  The waiter was rude and condescending from the beginning.  Every time he came to the table he took a shot.  He rushed us to order by saying, "I don't have time for you.  What do you want?".  I know that sounds hard to believe.  I also could not believe my ears.  At some point before dinner arrived, I just could not take it anymore.  I asked my family to walk out, and I stayed behind to complain to the maitre'd and to pay for what was on the table.

We were all smiles going in, and simply miserable going out.  

By the way, this happened over a year ago.  So you can see this experience has stayed with me.  I take every opportunity to tell people about my horrible experience there.  This doesn't mean this will happen to you, but I've never been treated this way and I've been to many, many restaurants.  This one really stands out - in a BAD way.  Good luck to you if you go.
author: Elena I.

description:
ok, bear with me. I like NB Restaurant a LOT. the surroundings are fab, the decor is classy and refined, the bar is damn beautiful, and it's one of a handful of places where the patrons seem to actually "dress up" instead of down. in reality, I don't come here for the food; I come for the ambiance and boy will you pay for ambiance, lemme tell you. I would come here just to drink, honestly, b/c the baby lobster tails I ordered were frankly mediocre -- rubbery and bland. my boy's petrale seemed a bit lackluster, as did our salads (Caesar & spinach). but 2 bottles of cab sauv later, the meal was all but forgotten.

now I'll get all gooshy and explain why I love this place. it was here that I realized I wanted to spend the rest of my life with my boy. forever, for eternity, etc. ok there, I said it, let's move on. if you come, bring lots of cash and/or plastic cuz it ain't cheap. and don't be a tightwad, let the valet park your car and tip generously, since they are good guys. and as you're sitting in the luxurious NB Restaurant surroundings, remember it was here that Prima made a lifelong decision that wasn't induced by booze
author: Prima D.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in SF, and i eat out quite a bit, it may be a little pricey but the service and the food are amazing. There has yet to be a time that i have received anything less than amazing service. This is one of the few places in N. Beach that is not full of tourists, but rather caters to a more local crowd. This place is way better than all those other restaurants that litter the area and attract tourists with their cheap themes.

I almost always get the veal piccatta, which is incredible every time. Most plates will run you about $22, and if you throw in some wine and an appetizer and you will be spending about $110 for two people.  

Also, i suppose i should mention that many of San Francisco's elite come by here on occasion.  I have seen both former mayor Willie Brown  and senator Feinstein here on separate occasions.
author: Amir K.

description:
The highlight of my evening involved watching my server douse my wilted salad with pepper using an electric mill that had some sort of flashing strobe light attachment.  Otherwise, the food was no different than the 42 billion other faux Italian tourists traps that populate this area. 

One star for said strobe light/alien homing beacon/ electric pepper mill.
author: Dave R.

description: The food is great, but this restaurant is really set apart by its service. The place is pure old school charm. Every time I come here the staff goes out of their way to make me feel like I'm part of the family.
author: Eric H.

description:
Our evening (Wednesday, pre BBB) began with an attempted upsell by the maitre'd on the wine selection.  When we expressed hesitation on purchasing the $90 bottle of wine he promptly exited and gave us no attention afterward.

Our waiter (Giuseppe), initially prompt and courteous, quickly devolved to an inattentive and soon to be purposefully avoiding waiter.  When he came back to tell us our meals would be served in five minutes, it was more like thirty minutes.

The food arrived and he used to stupid little alien pepper-grinder previously discussed by every other post.  By the way, I think it's pretty comical that is the ONLY positive thing the majority of the posters can agree on about this place.

When we told the waiter we needed to get our food because we have a show to see in 30 minutes he blamed us for the delay.  He actually said, "You should have told me, I would have made them do it faster".  This wouldn't be the first time that evening he would pull the same crap.

The bill comes, and it seems a little high but we were in a rush to get out.  I pay the bill and give the guy twenty percent, the food was good and he wasn't that bad, considering some of the places I've eaten.

Now comes the sh*t -- after BBB I take a look at the receipt to notice why it was so high.  They charged us for a fourth meal!!!

Needless to say we went back to complain, the waiter again blamed us and said "You were in a rush and ran out before I could tell you." blah blah blah.  They indicate they will reverse out that fee.

It gets better...I check my bank statement three days later to find that, not only have they NOT reversed the fee, instead they actually charged me AGAIN for that mean.  $26.04 x 2 = $52.08 in overcharges.  I called back to talk to Warren the manager on duty who told me to call the business office on Monday to get a proper credit.  Needless to say I will be requesting the entire gratuity back as well.

If they do not refuse to pay back the gratuity, I will dispute the entire charge with MasterCard.

Dine with caution.
author: Zach E.

description: I had dinner there a few weeks ago with friends and in spite of making a reservation two months in advance, they seated the eleven of us at a round table for eight, in the back near the kitchen... very uncomfortable. The waiter very quickly sold a few people on the idea of having a tomato & buffalo mozzarella appetizer & scurried away before I'd had a chance to cast a vote, and thee next thing you know we all had one of our own. In all fairness, it was good, but not at all what I had planned to have as an appetizer & certainly not good enough that I would ever order it again. I chose the veal saltimbocca alla Nerone as my entree, but before ordering it I asked the waiter how it differed from veal saltimbocca alla Romana (which I've had dozens of times over the years at dozens of restaurants all over the country) and he described it as being exactly the same as what I know as "alla Romana." The waiter also tried to push an overpriced bottle of wine from a vineyard we'd never heard of... he said the owners of the restaurant also own this particular vineyard... it wasn't bad, but in my mind worth perhaps a quarter of what they were asking, so we went with a few bottles of a well known cabernet instead. All things considered, my entree was very good, the appetizer was "just" good... & hard to get excited about, and the prices were set about 25% too high on most things and ridiculously high on others... $4.25 for one shot of espresso, really? Bottom line: I'd give the entree 4 stars, and award 2 stars to the service, uncomfortable table arrangement & high prices... so 3 stars overall seems fair... and I'm sure my friends would all rate the experience similarly. In conclusion, I can safely say that I will not be returning... the North Beach section of San Francisco has dozens of better restaurants to choose from.
author: Original 6.

description:
Owner Lorenzo is very busy catering to wealthy widows who don't mind paying $30 for a piece of  just ok lasagna that sells for half that price and double the size in neighboring "U.S. restaurant". My wife was celebrating her birthday and the waiter was informed. All we got was a "Happy Birthday" wish. I mean, we left so much $$$ behind, where is the courtesy of a little cake with a candle? 

The atmosphere is almost pretensious, yet still comfortable.
author: Ari t.

description: I am so disappointed with this restaurant.  I have eaten here a few times, food always very good.  This time I brought my own bottle of wine and had a good dinner.  Little did I know they have a $30 CORKAGE FEE.  Our waiter never mentioned the fee.  When I questioned him he got out the wine menu....which we never got a copy because we bought our own wine.  The manager simply said "that is our fee"...
author: Janet B.

description: North Beach is the perfect example of Little Italy!  The lasagna melts in your mouth and the appetizers with the house cured prosciutto and melon are an incredible treat. Everyone at our table ate every bite and was still raving about it this morning! This is always the first dinner we have when in San Francisco and usually the last as well! The service is over the top and the ambiance can't be matched. Enjoy!
author: Matthew C.

description: Excellent food, absolutely to die for. Waiter was a bit aggressive on making us order but what he suggested was so amazing that we didn't mind in the end. Sit downstairs for a different experience. Been here twice and would absolutely go again.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Shiny, generic Italian restaurant.  Charismatic old guy to greet you at the door?  Check.  Giant pepper grinder?  Check.

But it's expensive and the food was lousy - not even mediocre.
author: Ciaran W.

description: For the price, I was expecting incredibly delicious food.  The food was fine, nothing special.  The service was not great.  I had asked the waiter to bring a slice of cake with a candle for my partner's birthday after dinner and he didn't even get that right.   I was disappointed.
author: Miriam J.

description:
Great Cow of Moscow this place is awesome!!!!

I went here with a co worker and two colleagues 2 years ago.  As we walked through the front door, our jackets were immediately taken and put away for us in the cloak room and we were promptly seated at a great table.  My colleague had been to this restaurant many times before and they greeted him like an old friend, by name, a smile and a handshake.  The place had a kind of old school (not to old school boring though) San Francisco Italian restaurant feel.  Comfortable, friendly and welcoming.

As we were looking at the wine menu, ok so I was the one hogging the dam thing, the waiter recommended a bottle of a special wine that they have made specifically for the restaurant.  It was delicious, one of the best wines I had tasted all year (and at the price they were charging it dam well better be).  

So there we were chatting and the waiter asked what we would like for appetizers, it took more than 3 min for any of us to come up with an idea so the waiter said he would have the chef make up something off menu for us and if we didn't like it, we didn't have to eat/pay for it.  Like the wine it was off the meter.  I have no idea exactly what was in it, but prawns and white wine had something going on in there.  

By the time we got the appetizer, you guessed it, it was time for another bottle of that wine, note for future reference only 3 of the 4 of us are drinking.  When the waiter came back to take our dinner order, I told him to bring me anything (I have never done that before, I have never had the confidence in a new restaurant to just tell the waiter to bring me something he thinks I will like).  Again, by the time the dinner came it was time for a 3rd bottle of that wine (seriously it was that good).  My dinner was this chicken, prawn and something or other dish that I couldn't get enough of, I didn't ask what was in it, I didn't want to know, I didn't care,  I just ate it and every bite was heaven.

This place has fantastic service, without being to pushy or overly attentive.  And as I have said the wine and food are incredible.  The only down side is its expensive, I can only imagine our bill was upwards of $450, but as I wasn't paying I consider it well worth it...lol.
author: Carter H.

description:
This place was pretty good, but for the prices...not outstanding. Highlights include the carpaccio, coffee and bread.

Doesn't say a lot for the main courses, which had their bright spots (the sauce for my tortellini was creamy and delicious, the lamb wasn't cooked to order but was well seasoned)....but not for the prices they were offering them at.

If it weren't for the certificates from the time share, we would've been pretty pissed to pay as much for OK food (especially considering all that SF has to offer).
author: Cristian C.

description:
The Gotti's would feel at home here!
This place has the old world feel of the Italian Mafia...so the food better be good and it was! When you are eat here you are treated like famiglia!
Reason to Come Back:
The Mafia Wait Staff...and the food

 MAGNIFICO! CIAO BELLA!
author: A P.

description:
3.5 stars. ( waiting time and messy restroom)

You would think this place is pristine but in reality, I felt cramp. Nowhere near intimate, outdoor tables are non sturdy, food selection wasn't to my tasting. I think I prefer Thomas Keller's AD HOC to this place. Over rated for what it's really worth. The veal I had were a little over cook and the spinach was too wet. If I was the chef, I would make them a little crispy but I do like the chip-like potatoes. They were good. The calamari I did like. Other than that, I'm not really impress. I think the service is decent. Nothing near five stars. I expect the server to get the ladies chair, wipe clear our bread crumbs, refill our water without asking, check back on us to see if everything is alright. Since it has its fancy gold sign, it must be great. 

That's my two cents.  Go to DiMaggio's ( formerly the old Fior de Italia rest., it's much better.
author: Stanley K.

description: Parking is tough and the place is a tad small. The wine list is endless food is GREAT! The owner seemed to know everyone that walked through the door. I was only bothered by the fact that this is a hangout of that right-wing lunatic (Michael Savage).
author: Chad W.

description:
North Beach on a Monday night was typically quiet, except with North Beach Restaurant.  It was packed with patrons and celebrities when we went there.  Since my friend knows Lorenzo (owner) personally, we were treated with the VIP service.

We had a bottle of 2002 Petroni Poggio Alla Pietra (I wrote down the name of the wine).  It is from Lorenzo's personal winery.   It was really delicate and soft, which perfectly complimented our meal.  We started with the chicken consummate (really amazing chicken broth), escargot, and as the main course we had the seafood risotto, spinach ravioli, and pasta with clams (extra spicy).  

Although the food was decent, I can only recall how great the wine was.   My friends did love the private label olive oil, ravioli, and the pasta with clams.   

By the way, I accidentally compared the risotto similar to rice, and my friend (the Italian food snob) correct me by saying:  "Calling the risotto rice is just like calling the Mona Lisa a picture".   Oops.
author: Gin H.

description: This places screams touristy. Aside from that and the nasty fish smell which seemed to overcome me as I walked inside the restaurant, the food is really quite good and the service is awesome. I definitely recommend the tagliatelle with porcini mushrooms and the home made tiramisu.
author: Helen Y.

description:
i've been to the north beach... 5 or 6 times in the past year and a half... and i can say that the food quality is very consistent... but please be warned that it's expensive and there is definitely up sell on the appetizers....

my usual here is the prosciutto and melons... but the wait staff tend to always push the burratta... dont get me wrong... the burratta is very good... the cheese is freshly shipped from italy and it's very creamy and delish... it's like a fancier version of caprese salad... back to prosciutto... the prosciutto is VERY good! it's house made and hung in their dry meat room down stairs for 9 months before serving... it's well seasoned... and paired with the melon... the sweet and salty all at once is awesome!

caesar salad here is light and the dressing is packed with the taste of anchovies... i dont mind anchovies... i actually appreciate them... so it's good to me, but that's just a warning for those who dont like anchovy taste... the salad is dressed very light... not doused with creamy caesar dressing like in other places....

my usual entree here is Osso Bucco... i cannot sway from ordering this... it's the best.  the shank is perfectly cooked.... the only thing i can say is that the veggies can be more seasoned... 

dessert- the berries with zbaglione and the tiramisu are my two favs... it's good to end the night with something light and sweet after a heavy meal! 

service here is impeccable. all the wait staff is formally dressed and knowledgeable with menu and wine list.  but be warn, they are trained to upsell! haha be firm on what you want! 

in regards to wine... petroni wine is decent to good... depending on which one you order... but they are truly over priced!  they have a HUGE wine list... so you'll have TONS of choices...

say hi to Lorenzo when you go in...he's the stalky italian guy usually up front he's the owner.. Lorenzo is very charming... and he's usually there with a glass of wine in hand... what a job!  His son, Peter,  who may be the host of the night... he's lorenzo's son and he's GREAT! Peter is SUPER friendly!
author: Kelly H.

description: Killer place, but long lines.
author: Pratik A.

description:
I didn't know what to expect when I came here. As usual, my boyfriend and I rarely have a dining destination- we just kinda wander until we settle on something. So the other week it was a gorgeous day and we wanted to walk around North Beach. Lunchtime came around, and we wandered into here- neither one of us ever having been before. 

What really excited me was that they had polenta soup!! I loooove my polenta so when I saw this on the menu that was outside, I was sold. (Yes, I have random favorite foods) I got the soup and the petrale sole, another old standby. It was really good. Straight forward.

My only issue was, the servers were kind of strange- not really into the bowtie thing. And ours was a little spacey and forgetful. 

But, if I was ever wandering North Beach again, and felt like some Italian food I just might wander in here again to give it another shot.
author: Nina H.

description: This was the finest italian meal I've had on the west coast for sure and would put up a fight against other historical Italian restaurants in the US. The prosciutto and melon offering is great as is the room in which the meat is curing above your heads while eating. Waiter was very knowledgable and in fact offered to order for some in our party to which he did not disappoint!
author: Joe P.

description:
Food: 5
Decor: 4
Service: 5

I've eaten here about 20 times. I haven't always eaten as sometimes I just go in for drinks. This is a pretty authentic Tuscan style ristorante, as the owner is from Tuscany and it reminded me of the ristoranti in Florence.

The waiters speak italian which gives it a wonderful atmosphere and the service is always efficient and fast.

I've never had a bad experience and will continue to come here as one of my staples in the city. 
It seems to be a hangout of San Francisco socialites. Sure a lot of tourist come here but that's because of the reputation.

I've never had a bad meal and will continue to come back because of the staff and food.
author: Roger H.

description: Nothing to rave about at all.  We ordered two different apps, because the mussels had an awe full taste to them.  They tasted too much of cheap white wine, the broth was mediocre at best that they were in.  The mussels did not taste that fresh either, some were not open either.  It should not have made it on my plate if the mussel isn't open.  The crab appetizer was also disappointing, it tasted like it was canned crab meat.  Fresh lemon, and the cocktail sauce didn't help.  I should have walked out right then, with two disappointing apps.  Decided since a friend gave this place rave reviews, I'd stay through the main course.  That was a mistake, i ordered the osso buco veal shanks, the tomato sauce was too pungent and sour, the peas were undercooked.  The best part of the dish was the rice cake that came with the dish, the shanks were just ok.  I've made better osso buco using andrew zimmern's recipe for his shanks, if you want phenomenal food sometime it's better to make it yourself.  My girlfriends main dish was tasteless, the ravioli were bland and lacked any kind of seasoning.  I'd give this place 0 stars won't be back again, the only reason this place could get 1 star is their good selection of wines.
author: Andrei A.

description:
I give this place a 4 star rating for a couple of reasons:  First, they can seat large parties,  often on the same day.  That is a plus if you have corporate meetings and/or family gatherings.  Second, the menu can accommodate a variety of tastes and interests for even the pickiest eater.  There is more than just pastas.  There are meat dishes for the carnivores; seafood for the non-meat eaters and veggie dishes for vegetarians.  There is something for everybody.  My favorite is the veal scallopini a la Bruno.  It is the traditional veal scallopini with mushrooms and topped with pine nuts.  Good veal dishes are hard to find as it is, but here it is the best I've tasted.

The food is also very good.  Portions that will fill you and not overwhelm you.  My favorite dishes include the veal scallopini alla bruno (with mushrooms and pine nuts) and the prawns provenciale.  

My only gripe (which prevents it from getting the highest rating) is that they charge an outrageous $4 to add anchovies to your cesar salad!
author: Dale S.

description:
The food was not bad and its a good place to accommodate a large group (downstairs). Beware, they know how to pad your bill.  It's probably better to order individual appetizers to share vs. their suggestion as each person will get charged for the "dishes".  They also pour large amounts of wine in each person's cup, as if we were all alcoholics, with extra bottles laying in wait when we run out.  They also keep pouring their pricey bottled still water into our cups , even though they were full!  They also charge a $3 per person cake cutting charge.

p.s Even though its sounds novel, don't reserve their prosciutto room because...well it smell like old meat in there.  Not cool.
author: Ezduzit S.

description:
One of the better Italian restaurants in North Beach.  The tuxedoed staff drips old school class.  Some wise looking Italians in the back room compliment a largely upscale North beach clientele. 

The manicotti is excellent , as is the wine list which was surprisngly reasonably priced for an otherwise pricey place.

Having had the place recommednded to me by an ex cop as a particularly genuine mafiaesque eatery in North Beach, I found the space itself is surprisngly airy, light, and modern with high ceilings.

They take reservations. A great place to take visitors looking for authentic Italian in North Beach.
author: Codester H.

description:
Less cheesy than a lot of the restaurants in North Beach. The waiter gave us a nice table at the window and said "Miss, you take this chair you have a lovely view of the street on this beautiful day!" and then said to my counterpart "you sir! you get the other chair, in the shade and you get a lovely view of this lady!" At least the waiter sees my obvious beauty and charm.

Minus one star for the price. But hey, you cant win them all.
author: Erin F.

description:
I know that this place seems like a staple for tourists, but skip it. My stepmom was in from Ohio with her friends and really wanted to go here so we made reservations. When we arrived, we were treated rudely and stood around for 20 minutes before being seated downstairs next to a huge party. 

Everything was obscenely expensive, and the food was unremarkable. I've had much better lasagna in North Beach and for the price my portion was small. My stepmother and her friends were unimpressed as well and we didn't stay for dessert or coffee.

For a better Italian experience, head to E' Tutto Qua or Tommaso's.
author: Jessica C.

description: My fiancé and I had dinner here on 2/21/2014 and had a great evening.  I had the Osobucco and she had a pasta dish with asparagus.  She said it was one of the best meals she ever had.  Mine was good as well.  They picked a wine for us which while quite potent was delicious.  The only knock I would have is the ambiance, while very classy overall, I felt it was a bit too brightly lit.
author: Bill L.

description:
The good things first: the bar was really nice, the bartender was friendly and attentive.  The host was very friendly and accommodating.  We were seated in a little nook by the front window.
The ugly: our server was very condescending.  From where we sat, we could observe him taking care of two other tables.  He laughed and joked with them and was very attentive.  Quite the opposite when ever he came around to our table.  We were treated like a bother - tourists.  He didn't have the time or interest in us.  When it came time for dessert, he asked if we we were interested.  When we said yes, he immediately responded, 'cheesecake or tiramisu' as if that's what all the tourists order - he assumed we didn't have the taste or interest to explore the other options.
If were hadn't been able to see how he treated other patrons, locals, we would have guessed that's how he treated everyone.
Choose someplace else - where they don't care if you are a local or visiting.
author: Beth P.

description:
Was here for an event. Set menu. Pretty so-so. They made a really big deal about how they cure their own prosciutto and it's organic and amazing. It was very average - no character, just salt. The pasta course - penne w/clam sauce - was surprisingly good. Dessert was weird - a frozen thing with some zabaglione on top and a strawberry? Entrees were fine, old-school beef chicken or fish with some plain steamed broccoli on the side.

Service was just okay too. They were a lot more interested in making sure the train ran on schedule than making sure people had a good time. Silverware was tossed to people sitting in hard to reach places. At the end of the evening, as people were milling around and trickling out, there was some very brusque removal of plates, tablecloths, etc. from around people who were still seated.
author: Wangston P.

description:
If you want to be treated and cheated like a tourist, even if you're a local, here's your place. 

A group of us went there for a friend's birthday.  Everything about this place is overpriced and mediocre.  

The worst part, after our entrees (which we were rushed through), our waiter was appartently done with us so he dropped off the check.  He didn't ask if we wanted coffee, dessert or anything else.  And he gave himself a 20% tip (which came out to a couple hundred dollars.)

We asked for coffee and a dessert menu a few times, and he eventually dropped off a couple of cups of coffee but no spoons, no milk, no dessert menu.  Never saw the waiter again. 

I complained to the manager but he did nothing.  And the waiter still insisted on his 20% tip. 

Basically this place SUCKS.  The food is almost as bad as the service.  There are a ton of places in North Beach that are half the price and twice as good.
author: Derek M.

description: I took my client here who flew in from South America because I wanted to take him to a nice fancy restaurant and treat him well.  Overall, we had a negative experience.  We were seated in the back near the kitchen door opening where the waiters were coming in and out (even though we saw other more desirable tables available).  In short, our waiter was snooty and pushy, and nearly forced us to order a bottle of wine, even though we indicated MANY times that we did not want wine... but in order to NOT look cheap to my client we ordered 2 glasses of red wine.  The food was not terrible, but it was not very good.  The scallops we ordered tasted a bit funny.   The waiter annoyed us by serving food from our main dishes on to our plates, which was strange.  Perhaps he was trying to get a better tip.  Anyways, at the end he pushed us to order desert, and then made a snarky comment that sounded like we were cheap for not ordering dessert.  After I got home later that night, I became VIOLENTLY ill and vomited my guts out for about 30 minutes.  I was very sick for 2 days and also my client was dealing with stomach issues.  My entire body was destroyed and I couldn't even take my client out during the time he came to visit me.  I will never return to this terrible restaurant.
author: Peter J.

description: My favorite restaurant in SF. Never had a bad meal here and that goes for everyone I've brought to the restaurant as well. Wait staff is hit and miss, but the food is excellent. First time I went w/ friends, one from Italy. He said it was almost as good as his mama's cooking. Next time, friends said this restaurant ruined all other italian restaurants for them...this was the best. If you don't see anything you want on the menu (hard to believe), they'll cook something else up for you. Top notch all the way. Any veal dish is superb. Don't know about the reviews from ex-employees or people stating it's riddled w/ tourists. It never seems touristy when I'm there....maybe because I'm one of the tourists. Wow...never realized that before.
author: Eric M.

description:
Was taken here for a client dinner, shared the chef's tasting menu, and had a great time. 

Food is always much better when you don't have to pay for it. 

Thanks, Corporate America.
author: Jill C.

description:
Love, love love it.  Granted I have only been twice, but both times I experienced excellent service, amazing cocktails and delicious food - especially their house-made prosciutto and wine, both of which blew me away.  I work for a five star hotel in the city, and we were always sending people here when they inquired about local Italian eateries.  I had never heard anybody come back with anything but incredible remarks  - raving and ranting about the food and the "family" style service that they received.  Even I was sending people here, not having experienced it first hand - because I was that confident that they too would love it.  

Finally, I'd heard enough.  I rounded up the family & some friends, and off we went.  From the moment that we walked in until we were hugged goodbye by the manager, we felt incredibly comfortable & at home.  The staff was so attentive, it was as though they were anticipating our needs before we had a chance to realize them for ourselves.  When returning from the restroom, my napkin had been folded, and a server rushed to pull out my chair.  Just when I thought manners and old-world service had gone by the wayside, I found out where it's been hiding all along.

Although it can get a bit pricey, you will receive more than what you pay for in quality as well as quantity.  So go, enjoy it, savor the moment - and try that prosciutto.  You'll leave satisfied & smiling.
author: Whitney H.

description: This is simply the best Italian place in the Bay Area. North Beach offers classic Tuscan cuisine prepared to perfection! It is a favorite haunt of my family and other food-obsessed souls who murmur over the quality of the pasta dishes. BRAVO!
author: Patrick B.

description:
I'm a huge fan of this place; whenever someone asks me for a recommendation on italian food in SF, I always tell them to come here.  One of the only places that actually cooks all the pasta al dente so it's not all mushy and soggy by the time you eat it.

Contrary to the other reviews, I've never really thought that it's particularly expensive . . . strange.
author: Vicki Y.

description: Outstanding - held my mother's 70th birthday dinner here. Bui was especially accommodating, the entire group was treated beautifully. Food/wine wonderful. Very memorable evening. Thank you!
author: Maryliz B.

description:
When (and I do mean when) they offer you a taste of their special $90 a bottle wine, take it. Do I remember the exact brand, no. But what I do know that it is red, smells wonderful, and hits the spot. Live a little!

Get a table downstairs if you can, but not in the way back by the stairs unless you like a draft and smell of smoke from outside (the only real negative I found).   The food is very tasty and authentic, and the atmosphere is much nicer than most other Italian restaurants in North Beach. The waiters are from the old country and quite knowledgeable.  Look closely in the back and you may see one of the Goodfellas.  Overall it was a pleasant experience.
author: Dave L.

description:
Classic. Old-school.

I've been here several times with my family. We are always treated well here, it's always a pleasant experience. 

The servers couldn't be more nice. They all wanted to hold my brother's new baby, which I thought was really cute. We even took a picture of the baby with the waiter and when she's a bit older we're going to come back and take another picture.

The food is great, yummy Italian of course. 

Overall I just love North Beach Restaurant for the experience--the old world ambiance and solid Italian cuisine.
author: Sophie D.

description:
I was quite pleased with my first dining experience here this past Saturday.  Our waiter was absolutely charming.  We took his suggestions for appetizers:
their Famous Home-Cured Prosciutto & Melon and Sliced Tomatoes with Fresh Mozzarella.  The prosciutto was amazing.  We were told that the Mozzarella served in this dish is overnighted directly from Italy.  If it does not arrive in the morning, it is not served that day.  The cheese was fantastic as had a  very dense texture...it was also lightly drizzled with some balsamic vinegar.  Since I'm sensitive to salt, the layering of the prosciutto, tomato, mozzarella along with the a bit of the basil leaf created a wonderful balance.

My main course was the Veal Saltimbocca alla Nerone - Chef's Creation.  Upon inquiring what exactly comprises this dish, I was told that it would have a layer of cheese atop thinly pounded slices of veal with some gravy sauce and pine nuts with a side of herb roasted potatoes and blanched spinach.  I took the first bite of the veal and it was very salty....there was more prosciutto in between the veal and the cheese.  There were no pine nuts as the waiter said it would contain.  Although the dish wasn't exactly as I was expecting, it was still very tasty.

I would go back there again.
author: Michelle N.

description:
I'm being a bit generous with the star rating but what the hell, they make a killer lasagna!  The twenty minute wait is definitely worth it.  If you get a chance, definitely ask to be seated downstairs in their cellar.  It has a much calmer atmosphere since you're away from all the hustle and bustle. Prices are normal, I wouldnt expect an Italian restaurant in the heart of north beach to be cheap.


I recommend the lasagna, duh
Prosciutto with melon
Escargot
and the bf always gets the garlic butter linguini with clams
author: Tammy L.

description:
Overrated...
I've eaten here over the holidays for the past two years and largely I've been disappointed. First off, when I am at a restaurant where the average entree is $35+, I hope for excellent quality of ingredients and flavor. Not to say that North Beach Restaurant is bad, but it's not great and definitely overpriced. I ordered the Veal Chop, which came precut and closer to medium than medium rare. I understand completely that Italian food is done simple and let's the freshness of ingredients shine, but this was simply a redwine reduction over dry veal, a single potato cut into thirds, and a pile of underseasoned steamed spinach.
My brother (who is a bartender and server at a steak house), ordered the $45 new york strip medium rare--sadly it came to the table well done and dry. He politely informed the server that it was overcooked for his taste, to which there seemed to be too long of an upturned nose and awkward silence before taking it back. Almost as if defiant, a new steak was returned to us literally ice cold in the center and raw throughout. Aggrieved, but with sympathies my brother asked the waiter if it could just be slightly closer to a warm center as medium rare should be. The waiter, as if affronted, briskly snatched the plate back up and walked back to the kitchen. Finally, after our group was entirely finished eating, he was served a passable steak while the waiter hovered over my brother as he took a bite to see if it would be acceptable. 
A group of 13 people, and a $1150 bill later--I left unsatisfied.
author: Kevin J.

description:
I have been to quite a few of the Italian restaurants on Columbus--many of which are delicious!  I've never had to wait before either, but a couple weeks ago on a Saturday night, North Beach was crackin--unfortunately for me.  Every restaurant was packed and had at least a 30 minute wait, which isn't that long, but I was starving, so it was for me.  

Finally, we saw the North Beach Restaurant right off of Columbus and decided to look at the menu.  It was a little pricier than the others, but with barely a wait, we decided to try it.  It looks like a small place when you enter, but the host took us down a couple flights of stairs and I realized that this restaurant was enormous.  It kept going down and down and then it had tons of depth on the lower levels too!  There was even this awesome wine cellar!  

Anyway, the service was great!  The food was amazing!  I had the lasagna, which was quite possibly the best lasagna I have ever had.  Another cool thing was that you could pick whatever kind of pasta you wanted and then decide what sauce you wanted or if you wanted meat in it, etc.  You could order exactly what you wanted!  Has definitely become one of my favorite Italian places now!  So glad I ventured into it.
author: Danielle J.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in North Beach, and any North Beach frequent knows that there is a lot of competition. 

I have been here many times and have become good friends with the waiter Giuseppe. Anybody who is a regular of this restaurant knows who I am talking about. Anyway, the staff is always very generous and this is one of those restaurants I could spend hours arguing with myself over what to order. I recommend any of their veal courses or the swordfish. 

If I could only eat 1 item on the entire menu it would be their prosciutto and melon appetizer. They cure their own ham for the prosciutto in the basement (and if you get a tour you will most likely see a weird guy with slicked back hair wearing a tuxedo and eating a huge plate of pasta, very mobesque). 

There is not a course at North Beach that you will not like and it is perfect for a first date. It is fancy and elegant and it will not do damage to your wallet. Ask for Giuseppe as your waiter though, I promise you will not regret it.

They have a bar with a wonderful bartender (name escapes me) that is excellent to frequent. Their drink prices are very reasonable, especially for North Beach. My husband and I spent 3 hours there once!

If you want to plan a group dinner this is the place!!!! You can reserve the room where they cure the ham or the reserve the wine cellar. It is really incredible.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Do not come here if you are looking for a quick, in-n-out Italian dinner as you won't find it at NBR! The Italian attitude towards dining, particularly dinner, is that the meal is *supposed* to be long! If you know any Italians you'd know that the meals are always a hoot while generally lasting quite a bit longer than you'd have expected.

I've been coming here for about 4 years, semi-regularly, and my opinion of the place is this: they do the generics very well but they are not very adventurous; they stick to the guide. With this being said, the menu is still the traditionally extensive list of choices and although none are particularly unique, they are very delicious and I would comfortably recommend this restaurant to any of my friends for a simple, fun, and delicious dinner.
author: Alex T.

description: Great food and amazing wine list. Great selection of wines. Great staff and service.
author: David B.

description:
When in North Beach, North Beach Restaurant is sure bet.  I had the opportunity to join a group of friends for a Birthday dinner in the Parma Room.  We left everything up to the Waiter and Lorenzo and suffice to say all twelve of us were blown away with the service , quality of food and wine  and the ambience.
My previous visits have been in the main floor dining room and while not as extravagant as the aforementioned birthday dinner, each and every time has been enjoyable.  I may even join Lorenzo's wine club now!
author: Sean O.

description: Delicious Petrale Mugnaia. Perfectly cooked, every time. I wish I could have it every day.
author: Laurie N.

description:
The reviews gave me hope of finding a nice Italian meal in the heart of North Beach.  However, it turned into an evening of "things a restaurant should not do".
First, when I make a reservation, I do not expect to be seated in the rear, next to the kitchen door - that is where you seat walk-ins on an "as avaiable" basis...not folks who were required to leave a credit card to hold the seat (Opentable).  
Secondly, the waiter should not be condescending at their "approach" to the table...not so subtly adjusting the wine list every time he walked by.  If I want wine, I will order it.. if I don't... I don't.  
Fourthly, the wine steward should not...not..in no way.. not even a little bit... mock someone for not ordering wine.  No way... no how.  Not even THINK about it.  While my wife got a glass ($22) of the suggestion, I indicated that I would just be having water.  The steward began to not-so-subtly make fun of me for not having any.  No way. No How.  That should NEVER happen.  Whether is be for religious belief, health concerns or just personal preference... he should never even THINK about even making a subtle comment...and yet he did.
The food.. Oh yes... the food was good.  Not worth the price... but pretty good.  
Fifthly, when a patron asks about the meal (you remember the meal..the reason to order the wine), the waiter should either know the answer... or at least go ask the chef.  My wife asked about the cut of lamb on her plate.  The waiter said something to the effect of "It is a tender cut".  Well, yes... but WHICH one?  No shame in not knowing.. but go ask.
Lastly.. and certainly not leastly, never take a signed check off of the table until I leave.  Don't even think about it.... and never as this older waiter should have known... ask me to move my hand so that he can take it.  Holy crap... that is Restaurant 101.
Needless to say, we won't be going back.
author: David D.

description: We went here a few days back on a weekday night and it is very over-priced for the food they serve. The restaurant had a bad stink and the ambiance was very unwelcoming. The service and food are decent but not worth the high price. There are many better Italian places in north beach.
author: Al K.

description: Oso boco was excellant... My husband had ravioli tuscano it was also excellant a little pricey but worth it..service was good a little slow at times...only part that was poor was it was loud!!
author: Vicky C.

description:
had lunch for the 1st time here although i've lived in NB for 3.5 years. I was always cautious because it seemed to be overrun with tourists and suit-types. 
but i was rather pleasantly surprised by my pasta; linguine with porcini + scallops for $19.50. not the best pasta i've ever had, but pretty tasty. would have liked the pasta to be a bit more al dente, but hey, i didn't have to pay for it.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
I went here when my best friend was visiting. The Petroni family owns it and her last name is Petrone so it was an easy choice. 

It is a legit Italian restaurant in a legit Italian neighborhood. I felt a little under dressed wearing jeans with our server in a tux, but there were ladies next to me in running clothes so I felt better (though I wouldn't recommend running clothes). 

Our waiter was one of the best parts about the experience. First, he comes over and instead of asking us what we want, he asks what we are in the mood for so he can recommend something. That's a good waiter. My friend said she wanted meat, and he told her she had to get the duck - not something we would normally order. I knew I was in the mood for Veal Parm so I ordered that. 

We started off with two glasses of wine from the Petroni vineyard - unfortunately not the $20/glass Barbera. We decided to save that for when dad was in town. Then it was time for dinner. The waiter didn't lie about the duck. It was delectable - almost like steak, not what you would expect from duck. The veal was also great. Came out smoking hot and not too breaded or friend. It was high quality. I'm looking forward to going back for both the food and atmosphere. And will hopefully save room for dessert on the next trip.
author: Katie W.

description:
I have to say honestly that I don't completely remember the food here (I think it was awesome) because the setting was so incredible.  I went for a (quite wealthy) friend's graduation party and they rented the Prosciutto Room which features a ceiling covered in aging meat (a little disturbing for a vegetarian like me but amazing none the less.)

In any event if you can afford it I highly reccomend it for you next special event!
author: rhiannon g.

description: Fantastic food, great service and a lively atmosphere made for a really enjoyable business dinner for 6.  Switched to this place at the last minute and am so glad we did,  the house made prosciutto was delectable as was the burrata.  No complaints....amazing wine list.
author: Lisa B.

description:
Visited this restaurant twice. Both times I got in right away even though I didn't have reservation. Quite surprised actually since the restaurant was pretty packed. The service was great. During my 2nd visit there, our server even gave a free refill for my friend who managed to empty his glass of pinot grigio before the food came. Very thoughtful.

Their pasta is very good. Sauce is tasty, pasta cooked to perfection. I tried their penne carbonara and pasta della casa (on separate occasion!). My friends were satisfied with their halibut and veal scaloppine marsala. We weren't satisfied with their escargot though. It's too bland. Also, the bread was served cold (during both of my visits); it did taste a bit stale like one fellow yelper said. My friend said she had the bread served warm when she went there during lunch.

I would have given this restaurant 3.5 stars. Unfortunately, I can't. So, I decided to give it a 4 (wanted to extend my appreciation to that server who gave my friend the free wine refill and was attentive to us). Will I come back again? Probably for lunch. Their dinner price is a bit overpriced for my taste. Hopefully they'll really serve the bread warm during lunch. Oh yeah, this place also has quite an extensive wine list. I had their syrah, which was good.

PS: They have minimum charge of $20/person during dinner time!
author: Poof S.

description:
Talk about stuffy. 

A good scene for out-of-towners who want to feel classy. Not a good scene for somebody who is looking for a good meal. 

 Food=average
Service=average
Price=not f*ing worth it

A fancy Olive Garden.
author: Lee M.

description: This has to be my favorite Italian restaurant in the City.  For the first course we had prosciutto-wrapped cantaloupe with a delicious ripe red tomato topped with fresh mozzarella, balsamic vinegar and basil, along with miniature lobster tails broiled with garlic and butter, served with warm French bread; followed by a bottle of the2004  house sangiovese (Petroni label); and for the mail course I ordered chicken picatta.  After dinner, we went downstairs to the basement and sat at this long, granite table under about fifty hanging prosciuttos and sipped port.  Then we went back upstairs and had this amazing tiramisu.  It was a fabulous meal!
author: Marty Z.

description:
I liked Barbara J.'s comment, this restaurant is solidly good but not fantastic.  The artsmanship in food display is def. lacking, but then again, I got a Cioppino, and to make a seafood stew look pretty is kind of hard.   And on the other hand, again, my friend's pasta looked lackluster.  So yeah, artsmand ship:  C 

I didn't like that they had stacks of their table sangiovese in their boxes right behind my table, that sucked.  and i think my dog is now ripping apart her water bowl so i have to go...

---

Yes yes sydney got into the bathroom trash can, that was just nasty nasty nasty.  Anyway, back to the review.

So I made a reservation at NBR through Open Table and they made me give my credit card number just in case i cancelled, threatening me with a $20 per person cancellation fee if I didn't cancel w/in 24 hours, blah blah.  What a piece of bull, my friend and her parents were running late, they pushed it back until 8, then they were running even later, so I pushed it back until 8:45, we showed up at 9 and they were fine with it!  

It's a great restaurant for being right on North Beach's five points where there's lots of action.  It's traditional Italian, and it's a nice place to bring the folks.
author: Lindsay T.

description:
Solid cannelloni, but pricey.  Smarmy.  The waiter was apparently French, though I had the sneaking suspicion that he was faking the accent, though why someone would fake a French accent in an Italian restaurant is beyond me.

Be sure and read the commentary on the menu, which states that Italy taught France not only how to cook, but also how to eat with knife and spoon.  Them's fighting words!

Plastic black electric pepper shaker with red led light and spotlight was weird, out of place, but memorable.

Also, maybe I'm a bit picky, but I hate being made like I'm being cheap.  For a lunchtime meal:

"Would you like to have something from the bar, or just look at the wine list?"

"Um, no I think I'm ok with just water."

"Would you like tap water, or bottled water?"

"Uh, just tap water, thanks."

"Would you like it in a glass, or should I just bring the hose to your table?"

OK he didn't say that last part, but I felt like he'd said it :)
author: Corey C.

description:
Overpriced.
Service is good, food is decent, portions are small, wine list did not include decent bottles for less than $350 - $75 is as low as they go - come on - there's plenty of decent bottles out there for under $25 - what's up? 
Another surprise - we were a group and expected an automatic gratuity, but not one that was based on the alcohol and tax as well! This is really nickel-and-diming the customer (Remember? You don't tip on tax and alcohol).
Petrale sole is good. Prosciutto nice. Cioppino - lousy! Great cioppino comes in a huge bowl with tons of shell fish and can be a great mess to get through - this was a small, neat bowl with perfect, small chunks in it like they serve at Marie Callender's. Each bowl had exactly one muscle... the chicken sorrento was boring. Sweet breads so-so.
author: Thighmaster M.

description:
Some interesting reviews of one of my former places of employment. 
 
The second job I had after arriving in the City in '79 or '80 was as a valet for Lorenzo.  It was actually a pretty hip gig in a lot of ways - except when it was pissing down rain at 11:00 PM on a Sunday night in January and you're waiting for the last two couples to leave so you can get their god damn cars for them and go home and have a drink.

That you do get to drive a lot of interesting and exotic machinery is on the upside however and I'll bet I've driven more models of Ferrari and Maserati than you have.

As part of a crew of wise-ass valets, we took great pleasure in ragging on tourists, the sons of prominent local politicians who used to pull up in front of NBR with empty beer bottles rolling around on the floor of their cars, washed-up movie stars and other sundry quasi-comical regulars that frequented the place.

The other thing we used to do constantly was make fun of the prices, which were as out of sight then as they apparently are still.  Put it this way - none of the guys who parked cars there could ever afford to pay for a meal where they worked.  Consequently, all I ever really had there in terms of food was the plate of plain pasta with olive oil, fresh chopped parsley and grated parmigianno that they would give you at the start of your shift.  

It was quite good actually, so there are my two stars...
author: dave a.

description: I ate at N. Beach Restaurant last week and thought it was great.  We had a group of 5 and the waiter suggested the appetizer sampler.  Each of us got a plate that contained caprese salad with awesome burrata, prosciutto wrapped melon and more.  We also got a sampler plate of pasta with a seafood rigatonni, gnocchi, and mushroom risotto.  So good.  For dinner I had the filet of lamb.  OMG.  Could not have been better.  Dessert was another sampler plate with tiramisu, strewberries n cream, chocolate mousse, and cheesecake.  The best part was the wine.  The waiter was very knowledgeable and made several amazing suggestions.  Everyone should go to N. Beach at least once.
author: Ana W.

description: Wonderful service! Savory and delicious meals. I would very much like to be a patron again.
author: Megan B.

description:
Extensive wine selection and even better service!! 

Gnocchi is an incredibly difficult dish to master but they can rock it out!
author: Joanne B.

description:
Went here on a special occasion with family.  This restaurant is THE place to go in North Beach, according to a good business associate of mine in the industry.  And, I agree!

The entrees were excellent, though, the bread served before hand was stale as well as the olive oil.  A minor complaint.  

You will find an excellent though expensive wine list here.  This was the treat of my father-in-law, who is on a fixed income.  On price bases alone, he ordered a very good Napa B&V red for $50.  North Beach Restaurant has a great wine cellar if one desires the more expensive imported wines.
author: Billy Dee R.

description:
I've been here before - the quality of the food is decent enough to make a return visit.  The reason for one star? The AWFUL experience with the valet service.  It's understood that the valet service isn't owned and operated by the restaurant, but they should at least do their diligence to make sure that the drivers are good patrons of the neighborhood.  

Tonight on my way home they parked a car in the middle of the road (without four-ways on) causing a back up in North Beach... which is never fun.  I honked my horn to get their attention, but a driver came running out into the street flailing his arms... so i flicked him off.  

The driver completely lost his cool and chased me three blocks to where I was parking at a friend's house. Yeah, I flicked him off. But does that warrant a valet driver to ream me out in public? I think not.
