I will not return to the North Beach Restaurant as long as they have this pitiful excuse of a  valet service catering to their customers.  They have no consideration to the residents of the neighborhood and I refuse to give my money to a company that uses them.
author: Matt H.

description:
The food is OKAY, but a let down relative to what everyone was telling us. More to the point, the service was pretty awful. We went with a friend, who decided to get some wine by the glass. The waiter took her order and promptly left the table, not bothering to take my wife's or my own orders. After he passed by our table again we told him we'd like to order some wine as well, to which he gave us a rather vicious look as if to say, "What, you want to drink too??" I've been to rude joints, but this was the first time I felt outright hostility. 

Also, I really don't understand the people who think this is a fancy meal ... the decor is absolute crap (i swear those are school cafeteria chairs) ... at the same time, you could choke on the stuffiness.

Finally ... the pepper was the stale stuff in bottles ... you'd think that at this price they'd at least have fresh pepper (I think even Pomodoro, a CHAIN RESTUARANT, has this)

The more I think about this restaurant, the more I think how much of a waste of money and time it is. I guess it's where the wealthier tourists go instead of Calzone's or Stinking Rose or whatever ... more power to them. 

If you want good Italian food in North Beach make your way to Ideale. The food is delicious and their friendly service, needless to say, is much better.
author: hugh k.

description:
just got back from north beach restaurant....

liked it!!!

just like....

food is good... nothing spectacular.... just liked it...

service ..... just liked it....

the setting.... just liked it....

price..... hhmm.... ok.... kinda liked it....

something different to say..... this place is pretty damn italian....OO

so if  your looking for italian..... just do it...

ciao...
author: Mike K.

description:
There was a whole lot of veal on the flip side.
Gnocchi was good.
But it was all in the moustache.
author: Tu R.

description: Went there last night with friends from out of town. We selected north Beach Restaurant based on what I heard about the food. The location was easy to find. The staff for the most part was nice. Our waiter was a young man, probably only a few days on the job and this is where the experience starts to decline. We ordered one appetizer for the table and he brought three, the tiramisu was like a cold soup. It could even resemble the desert because it was so soupy. When the bill came we noticed we got charged for a Burata that was never ordered. We also got overcharged on each entry. We got charged for six when we only ordered three, charged for two prawn cocktails when we only ordered one. When we brought it to their attention, no came to apologize. all they did was grab the bill and bring back the revised bill with the Burata still on the bill. Needless to say we are not going back. With all the fine restaurants in North Beach this place should be embarrassed to identify itself as the symbol for a great neighborhood of San Francisco
author: Jim M.

description: Excellent service and food.  Go if you want a fine, formal and delicious experience.
author: Frank P.

description: The North Beach Restaurant is one of my "celebration" restaurants, a place I go for birthdays or special occasions.  It is better for small parties, or on weeknights, because it can get crowded (it's a small place) and the staff harried by customers expecting some Serious Service for their money.  It is expensive; too expensive for me to be more than a few-times-a-year treat, but I really enjoy dining there.  I've always found the ambiance pleasant, the service attentive and old-fashioned, and the food exceptional.  I almost always get the gnocchi gorgonzola, which is absolutely perfect.  I've also had the wild mushroom tagliatelle, which was excellent.  My friends rave about the proscuttio and melon appetizer, and I love the palate-clearing lemon-ice seriously alcoholic thing the restaurant sometimes includes on the house.
author: Jude F.

description: North Beach Restaurant is the pinnacle of the italian cuisine in North Beach. Literally everything that is on the menu is out of this world, not to mention the single serving size could easily feed two. Their wine selection is huge and the waiters are extremely helpful in helping you pair the food and drink. Though it is very pricy, I would say with out a doubt it is worth every penny all the way.
author: Sean MC E.

description: Me and my fiancé came here last weekend and the place was great. We showed up a little under dressed. (online said it was pretty casual) They did not make us feel awkward about it but were very helpful and showed us right to our seats in which we had booked on OpenTable. The waiters were all very nice and polite. Our waiter was very knowledgeable of the menu and answered any questions we had. My fiancé is a chef so of course we are usually pretty critical on the service/food/overall dining experience. We had appetizers and each ordered an entrée. He go the veal which was AMAZING and I got chicken (don't remember my dish name) which was awesome. I was SO full after leaving there. It was def. worth the money for the service you get and the quality of food.
author: Jessica W.

description:
I was here having a meeting luncheon with my boss and several attorneys for work...and this place wasn't that great. The bartender was kinda cute but looked like one of those cocky jerks that you'd want to punch in the face if he opened his mouth. I couldn't understand our waiter with his thick Italian accent and it looked like he had something stuck between his teeth, maybe it was a gap? I don't know....

Our appetizer came out and there were 2 slices of prosciutto (salty) over a slice of cantaloupe, two lobster tails (which were really salty as well!) and a thick slice of tomato with some weird gooey white cheese on top of it and some balsamic vinegarette. It was pretty good but eh...I would've much rather had some fried calamari.

Everyone pretty much had drinks except for three people...the waiter just kept pouring wine like there was no tomorrow...even after I told him I didn't want any red wine. I had some hot water with lemon and dude...the cups were tiny as hell! Like I was having a tea party with a Queen, sipping tea and munching on some crumpets! Can't really complain though....they did give me a little tiny teapot filled with hot water and a plate of lemon slices to refill on my own. =)

We had a pasta sampler which was pretty good....that was probably the only real yummy thing there. The sampler had gnocchi (I think that's what it was) in some marinara sauce or something, risotto with mushrooms (YUM!) and the tube-y pasta in a kinda spicy alfredo sauce.

I ordered their special: swordfish in a tomato-garlic sauce. It was pretty good, I couldn't finish it. One of the attorneys decided he wanted to finish off my plate...it was kinda weird but that's another story I will save for later. The potatoes were kinda dry and really salty. I really liked the spinach or whatever the hell kinda greens they were.

The waiters were quick to clear your plate...maybe they had nothing to do? I don't know....but damn, let me finish my food first or at least ask if I'm done with it. Don't just take it away...I felt like smacking the waiter's hand the second/third time around and say, "Don't touch!" I wanted more bread to eat with my extra olive virgin oil and balsamic vinegarette but they didn't bring any more out. =(

Our dessert was a slice of cheesecake, slice of tiramisu, slice of chocolate mousse (I think that's what it was...I wasn't paying attention, I just ate it), several strawberries that you can dip in a vanilla cream thingy all served on a silver platter.

I don't think I would come back to this place, unless I could afford it. Eleven people for a grand total of a whopping $1600. I don't think we will be coming back anytime soon to hold our annual attorney luncheon meeting. Nice place, just really expensive and the portions were not that great. But what else would you expect from an upscale fancy schmancy Italian restaurant in the heart of the North Beach area?
author: V M.

description:
Appetizers were exceptional. The wine selection is extensive, although our host kept the massive book that is their wine list at his fingertips. Cocktails were mixed to perfection, my sweetie favors a dirty martini, hers was filthy, and I mean that in a good way.

Dinner was very good, but not great. My sea scallops were cooked to perfection, as was my sweeties veal. The green beans were good, not great, and the potatoes were nothing special. Normally I would not be so critical, but at the prices they charge with the quality of service given, I have high expectations. That said, I would return without hesitation. The food, service, and atmosphere were all very good.
author: Tom A.

description: Appropriately placed in Little Italy, this is one of the better Italian restaurants I have tried. Their homemade lasagna is very good as is their vongole. A bit cramped but appropriate to the Italian feel. My biggest knock is that out of the times I've ate here, the food's been a little inconsistent. Overall, it's good.
author: Barrett I.

description: Love this restaurant.  We have a family dinner here every Christmas and it's really excellent. Service is wonderful, wine is top class and food.... OMG :). 5 stars is absolutely accurate !
author: Peter D.

description:
What is it with lack-luster Italian restaurants in North Beach!?!? I've always walked past the swarms of people at NBR (mostly old mafiaoso type grandparents with pimp cars parked outside) and have always heard that this place offered true old school italian fare. Unfortunately, it didn't do much for me then any other place in the 'hood. I had the pasta bolognese and it can be summed up with a big fat "eh". If you can't do that well, why go on? Hit me up with an Olive Garden already...

Drawbacks? I don't know. You get what you pay for I guess. Mediocre italian food set in the tourist trap of North Beach.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: I came here a few months ago for lunch with my SO. I wasn't feeling well at the time but we were in the area and how could you not get Italian food when you're in North Beach? I was craving carbonara so I ordered carbonara and was not disappointed. I also felt tons better after I ate! :) The service was fantastic and the restaurant has an inviting ambiance. It's a bit on the pricey side but I will definitely be back to try other things on the menu!
author: Bella L.

description: The old bait and switch was on that night. We were dressed up in sport coats and ties. We had a reservation for four persons and were very pleased with the initial ambiance of the restaurant at the front door.  But wait! That room is not for you.  You will be led by the well tanned silver haired headwaiter to a set of stairs and pointed down into a cellar room with a thoughtfully decorated glitter ceiling and lots of sewer pipes and large tables with the crying babies and rushed waitresses slapping food around in a manner reminiscent of an army mess hall.  Not only that, the food was very expensive.  If it had been my reservation that I had personally made I would have balked at being led to the chump room.  Never again.
author: Doug M.

description: Had dinner here last night with my husband.  Very busy which is great to see.  Had a lovely evening.  We had reservations and were seated immediately.  Very pleasant  waiter.  White table cloths and the style of restaurant that my husband particularly likes.  Wonderful Olive Oil that they have bottled just for them.  Caesar salad and Pollo Mattone -- both very good.
author: Vicki B.

description: I was sent here by the concierge at the Mark Hopkins Hotel in 2009. That was a Sunday night and I was dining alone. The restaurant was very quiet as it was Labor Day weekend. I mention this because many restaurants fall down on a slow night and oftentimes waiters neglect a solo diner. Not the case here. The food was excellent; do try the pasta bolognese to compare a standard dish. You'll find it correctly done with ground beef, ground veal and ground pork combined. In May 2011 I returned. During a four-day trip to SF, we ate there two nights. The food was still every bit as good. Our waiter was much better the first night than the second, but the consistently superior food at the restaurant will have me coming back each time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Jim B.

description: I used to eat here all the time but I have to say in recent months it is clear they have lost it. What was solid service and good food at a reasonable price has become poor service, over crowded, and the food just isn't that good anymore. I am not sure what happened but unless they improve quickly I can't see them doing more than living off their past rep. The take go "slice house" is even worse...I got a sandwich there today that frankly I would not even feed to my dog. It is sad they have fallen so far.
author: art a.

description:
Not too bad if you don't mind dropping $100 for a Saturday afternoon lunch.

Good location for people watching.
author: Eric G.

description:
I don't know where to begin. I realize we were here because we had to seat a large number of people, but with MONTHS of advanced planning, they couldn't figure out how to handle separate checks for groups of us? Ok, fine. That's one point off.

Food... polenta "soup" was ketchup with grits, as far as I'm concerned. With a square slice of what looked like potentially provolone cheese melted on top of it. Ew. And I LOVE cheese. What the hell is this?

Second course - entree.. Halibut (which, btw, is not TUSCAN at ALL) with overcooked, flavorless greens (chard, I think, judging by the amount of stems served to me) and 3 round slices of overcooked potato. What is this? I can make homefries better than this. The plate was literally divided into thirds, with fish, potatoes and 'greens' taking up each portion, and a bright lemon wedge. I've had better "Italian" food at Olive Garden.

We were in the basement (wine cellar room?) to accommodate a presentation we had to do, but rather than close the partitions that would separate us from the bar area, we got to hear staff scrape chairs around the floors, drop trays and dishes, move out to the kitchen... it was not an easy place to 'enjoy' a dinner at.

When we were ready for the slide show to start (after dinner had been cleared), we weren't even offered coffee, tea or dessert. That's $300 more they could have made on our already gouged prices. Seriously - $29 for linguine with clams? You gotta be kidding me!!!

I can't for the life of me figure out what was Tuscan about this place. Other than the tiles, which for the record are NOT edible, nothing screamed authentic here. I've been to Tuscany and it's lovely. I have been to North Beach Restaurant... and it is not.

Pass.
author: Allison E.

description: Very nice service.  Disgusting food.  How did they make Italian food so bad?
author: Christi C.

description:
To sum up this restaurant in 4 words: health code violations galore!

A friend and I went here one night for drinks and food. It was crowded (for some reason) so we sat at the bar, which was fine. The bartender barely gave us the time of day until she realized we were ordering food and would have a bigger check for her. Then the health code concerns started appearing:

-first, a dog was in the restaurant (not outside on a patio, but indoors), oh and not just sitting on the floor of the restaurant, but up ON THE BAR....yes, the same bar where we were eating. My guess is it wasn't a guide dog....

-next, the bartender is petting the dog and doesn't WASH her hands in between touching the dog and touching peoples' food and drinks. 

-then, she served us our appetizer and while she was setting down the plate, she placed her fingers in our dipping sauce! I'm sure it was an accident, but then she walked away as if nothing happened and didn't even REPLACE the sauce (reminder, her fingers had previously been touching the dog).

-lastly (I think this is the last one, although there were so many issues that night you would have thought we were watching Seinfeld), but lastly, the same bartender was also the coffee/cappuccino maker. She was making someone's cappuccino and some of the foam started flowing over the side of the mug. So what does she do? She wipes up the foam with HER FINGER (yes, still dog fingers) and then puts her fingers IN HER MOUTH to lick off the foam! Oh yeah, and even after that she didn't stop to wash her hands!

Good luck to anyone who is brave enough to eat/drink at a place with dog-haired-sauced-up-licked-clean-fingered bartender, but I will never go there again. 

I must say I'm glad we sat at the bar; if we had been at a table we never would have seen all of that stuff.

Oh, and after all that, the food wasn't even that great.....
author: Kate M.

description:
Snobby service with major attitude. Food wasn't great, but seriously overpriced. For a $25 pasta dish, I expect perfection. I got overly saucy, slighly overcooked pasta with previously frozen shrimp. The wine list was confusing and lacking in real variety. Your choice was either a $38 bottle of plonk or $100-$500 bottle of Cab. Will not be returning, or recommending.

Got a good chance to look at Willie Brown, tho'.
author: Mona S.

description: a restaurant I remember fondly was visited today and was a great disappointment.. eggplant parmigiana was tasteless and veal Milanese was quite ordinare. nothing exceptional to merit the prices.
author: ira l.

description:
One of the best Italian restaurants in SF. Can be pricy, so expect a bank loan tomorrow to pay for dinner. But worth it. The food is scrumptious and they even prepare off menu requests. Loyal staff that remembers everyone and treats everyone like big shots. Fun place and great bar.
Try Lorenzo's own wine label, what a surprise!
author: bill b.

description:
I had some clients in town who wanted to check out North Beach and eat some good Italian I had my assistant book something the would take reservations. I had never been here so had no expectations. 

Ambiance - 4 stars
Over friendly fakey Italian staff - 4 stars (prego)
wine list - three stars
prices .... ouch 2 stars very pricey
food - lets just say i love good Italian food and this place really let me down. it's mediocre at best - 3 stars

Bottom line if you want a night out in a really cool old building and a nice bottle of wine than this is your place, but if you want to have some kick ass Italian food, i would dig through yelp and find a place that focused more on the menu..
author: Michael V.

description:
This place lays claim to be high-end Italian in the wasteland of North Beach.  You enter and note the hyperkinetic host and waitstaff all bedecked in somewhat tattered tuxedos.  Shabby chic, akin to the heroin starved look of models a few years ago. 

Your waiter makes it clear from beginning to end that he could give a damn about you.  He certainly won't take time to tell you about any specials that might be available and any suggestions are perfunctory, as easily obtained as extraction of a recalcitrant wisdom tooth.  

Food can range from homey to hopeless.  My second, and last visit, included a veal dish that arrived at the table within seconds.   The pseudo veal had none of the consistency of real meat, but the sauce had the consistency of Elmer's glue all, glop.  

On my first visit tiramisu was lovely.  On my second visit dessert was just a plate of something or other.   These guys get by on statistics.  If enough tourists pass, a few will trip through the door.  Best that you keep a steady gait and pass this place by.  They, as every restaurant, should earn their customers one good meal at a time.
author: David D.

description:
Tourist trap. Good thing I was a tourist this Sunday night so I'm going to chalk up this overpriced dining experience to a bad, "Hey, while you're in town, check out..." recommendation from a co-worker. It's painful to pay so much, just to find out a place sucks (at least for me).

I walked in the door and was reminded by the host that I didn't have a reservation. If that didn't make me feel unwanted enough, the second host ignoring me alone at the front door, did the trick. When sat, they handed me a 3lb wine list but didn't bother with any specials. The service was professional but at the expense of watching waiters seemingly stumble over each other like card servants to the Queen of Hearts. I appreciated the effort but that type of vibe made me feel rushed to order and hawked to finish eating.

The food was slightly above average but priced well above that. As a tourist, I couldn't recommend a better place to go, but I can warn you not to go here.
author: Andy G.

description:
A classic San Francisco establishment -you can really see some old-timers here.  The waiters and the hosts were proper and extremely courteous. The setting was very old-fashioned, classy-mafia-esque, loved it. HATED the red-vinyl chairs hidden under the gorgeous white table clothes. 
After some bubbly, our night was abruptly interrupted by a CRAZY patron who was THREATENING all the waiters. I was told that he was a regular... If I were NBR, I would make him irregular.
author: Rada I.

description:
This restuarant is over priced, has an attitude, is not open to special requests. We no longer order anything to drink except the water becuase they (at least they use to) charge for refills for even ice tea!

But they do have an awesome pasta - called Spaghettini Lorenzo - and that is why we go back periodically. It is a very simple pasta - made with spaghettini or angel hair, tomatoes, garlic, and basil.

Except today when we were there. It was made with regular spaghetti - and had the garlic - one leaf of basil only - and the tomatoes were different - crushed and saucy instead of fresh tasting. 

We were hungry and it wasnt bad - it just wasnt right. When we were done we asked the waiter if they had changed the recipe - and I have to tell you - he was very quick in his lie - when he told us if we didnt want SPAGHETTI we had to specify which pasta we wanted - so why is it called SPAGHETTINI??????

Different bartender too - she poured a very light glass of wine, which isnt up to their standards. Different maiter d' - none of the usual waiters - wonder if there are different owners?

We were very disappointed today.
author: danielle n.

description: One of the better Italian experiences I've ever had.  Home cured prosciutto?!  Home made buffalo mozzarellal?!  Dinner was phenomenal.  Based on the 3.5 star rating, maybe I caught North Beach on a good night, but if so, lucky me.  It was really, really good.  Our waiter was awesome too... heavy Italian accent we could barely decipher, but excellent recommendations, great timing and good attitude.
author: Michael C.

description:
It is so hard to determine a star rating for a restaurant.  The criteria is so subjective and what you get from a restaurant oft times depends on what you expect from it.

North Beach Restaurant was not on my short list of eateries to try out.  It is located in a touristy section of North Beach and I am a Haight and Mission kind of guy.  When our out-of-town guest and his girlfriend picked the place, I said "must be in North Beach."  I am my own favorite comedian.

Our guest is a wine snob of some repute.  He has a gazillion dollars and an extensive wine cellar to match.  He picked NBR mostly because of its wine list and he was not disappointed.

Him:  I own a case of the 1946 Chatueu Somtinspecial.

Me:  I own a case of the 2006 Charles Shaw Syrah.

I am not sure what he ordered, but it was a sangiovese of some complexity.  It was monsterously good and it cost much as you might imagine.  

As for the rest of the place...  I cannot brag too much about the service.  It was a slow evening and the waiter hovered.  He was some ancient Italian man who liked to tell us stupid stories about bad customers of yesteryear.  I kept wondering if the accent was for real.  Do people really talk like that outside of the movies?

The food came quickly and it was hot, nicely plated and served with a flourish.  There was just so much hyperbole surrounding a simple Ceasar salad and a plate of carbonera.  The Carbonera, a specialty of the house according to the menu, was nothing special.  I have eaten much better meals at much better prices and just down the block.  

Most of the guests were at least business casual and we came in jeans.  Previous reviews have the place decribed as casual and I am not sure if that is true.  Having said that, I don't think our attire made a difference in the way we were treated.

Our ladies ordered desert and we shared tiramisu and cheesecake with four forks and two plates.  The tiramisu was just way below par for an Italian restaurant.  I have eaten mounded coffee goo in New Jersey truck stops that was far superior.  The cheesecake was very passable, but I have always believed it is hard to scew up a New York Cheesecake.

NBR gets big points for its superior wine list which gives it a three star rating on its own.  There is much to dislike about every other aspect of this place.
author: Cheezy P.

description:
I wanted to like this place: Italian-speaking waitstaff, rabbit on the menu, house-made prosciutto.  But our table was like the land that time forgot. I am guessing that the two tour buses that debarked straight into the restaurant got all of the house's attention. And the food (other than the prosciutto) was forgettable.

Since the prosciutto was amazing, two stars.  Come for an appetizer and a cocktail, then eat somewhere else (like, say, L'Osteria del Forno, which is small enough that the staff couldn't ignore you even if they tried!).
author: J P.

description:
We came to North Beach recently to celebrate a birthday, although we have been here several times throughout the years.  This is an authentic  Italian restaurant with a fabulous wine cellar.

Food-4
Aside from the food that my Sicilian mother-in-law makes, the food here is the real deal.  We started with the burrata special ($39 for 2.5 portions).  The kitchen split the portions and served everyone in our party with a personal plate...nice touch.  The creamy cheese was plated with a tomato and a basil leaf.  Simple and delicious.  For mains we ordered the Tagliatelli Bolognese (Pasta w/Meat Sauce $20), Gnocchi Piemontese (Potato pasta w/red sauce $19), Mare Chairo (tube pasta w/shrimp and tomato in a cream sauce $24), Veal Sorrento (Veal w/tomatoes and mozzarella $26), and Veal Parmigiana (Breaded Veal with tomato sauce, mozzarella, and parm cheese $29).  The veal dishes were the highlight.  The meat was tender and not overly breaded, like you typicaly find in an "American-Italian" restaurant.  The three pasta dishes were very good, and the pasta was hand-made. The only thing off was the gnocchi.  The sauce tasted jarred.  It probably wasn't, but it needed some help.  For dessert we shared the semifreddo ($8) and 2 cold zabaglione with fresh strawberries ($14.50 each).  Although a little pricey, the zabaglione with strawberries (flavored cream-like mixture with fresh sliced strawberries) was awesome and a must order at North Beach!  The semifreddo tasted like tiramisu and had a strong liquor flavor, which our table enjoyed.

Drinks-5
The wine list is fantastic.  We wanted to try something new, and the wine steward offered a great bottle of red ($56).  We were also offered a free sample of their house wine (they own a vineyard) which was a nice touch.  You can get lost in the wine list, so definitely ask for a recommendation.  The team will find a great bottle within your price range.  Full bar also available, and we enjoyed a bourbon (Maker's) after dinner.

Service-4
Our server was attentive and did a great job refilling our wine glasses, checking on us frequently, and making a few jokes.  The thick Italian accent added to the experience.  The only qualm we had was that after we had finished dessert, we sat for a good 20 minutes before our check was given to us.  (My wife actually had to go ask for the bill).  Other than that, top notch.

Decor-3
The decor is no frills, but the tables are cozy and the dinning room is flanked with hundreds of wine bottles.  For a special occasion, request the wine cellar.  (We opted for the main dining room).  The bathrooms could use some help.  My wife went to use the restroom before we left, but they were out of toilet paper and the bathroom was a mess.

North Beach is a great spot for Italian Cuisine in the city.  Manga!
author: Robert K.

description: Great service and ambiance and a real North Beach feel.  The food is typical Italian-San Franciscan and the prices tend to be a little on the high side.  All in all, a nice experience and I will dine there again.
author: Terry L.

description: All around, great food, service, wine, atmosphere.  Excellent experience, especially when someone else is paying.  Sat across from Nancy Pelosi.
author: Rob G.

description: Went here with my husband for an anniversary lunch.  We were just wandering around trying to find something that looked good.  Our server was nice enough, but the food didn't really impress either of us.  To me the food for the quality was way overpriced, everything was just okay.  The service was okay, the food and ambience were ok.  The thing that kind of put me over the edge was our drinks.  There were no soft drinks on the menu, so we asked if they had them and they said yes.  We each ordered a diet coke.  The were really small, and when they were empty the busboy asked if we would like some more.  We said yes and he got us some.  When we got our bill we were charged twelve dollars for four sodas.  Granted I probably should have asked if there were free refills or how much they were, but three dollars for approximately 8 oz of soda seems a bit high for me.
author: Whitney B.

description:
I came here this past weekend for my friends bachelor party and I have mixed feelings about this place. When we first arrived at the restaurant it was apparent that we were a bit under dressed compared to the other guests. But it wasn't a problem since the staff didn't really treat us any different.

We sit down and peruse the menu over a couple of cocktails. The server comes over and talks about the specials and to see if we want any anti pasta. This is where things go array (Always know the price of something before you order it). We wanted to try their prosciutto so he tells us about their sampler anti pasta that has prosciutto, caprese salad and some type of scampi. So they bring out the anti pasta and I have to say it was amazing. The caprese salad had the ripest red tomatoes and the buffalo mozzarella was delicate and creamy. The prosciutto was salty, tender and easily better than the Boarshead brand I am use too. The scampi was equally fantastic with mini lobster tails and this sauce that I couldn't get enough of. When we were finished, we all thought if the anti pasta was this much food we are never going to finish our entrees. Well we were wrong, the portions were pretty small compared to the appetizer. I had the lasagna which I was a little bit disappointed with. The sauce had a similar flavor to chef Boyardee. So we all finished up and the server dropped off the check to my friend. He looks at us and said in shock, "it's $580" (7 people but no wine). I quickly grabbed the check to find the caprese was $55 prosciutto was $55 and the scampi was $115 for a grand total of 225 for an appetizer. I know it's our fault for not asking the price but come on now. You should have a little discretion before you offer that. I will not be coming back unless someone else is paying. And if so, I hope we get that anti pasta platter because it is truly was amazing.
author: Jeff P.

description: I was here 15 years ago and had a fantastic meal. When I went back recently, I didn't remember that it was quite so "dressy".  The 6 of us had just finished working an event.  We were exhausted when we finally got to the restaurant on foot.  The manager (?) ushered us in immediately (we didn't have a reservation).  The food did not disappoint.  The homemade proscuitto was memorable.  I could have had proscuitto, cheese and wine and called it a night.  We all ordered different entrees and had appetizers to share.  Everything was delicious.  Old school italian.  Yum yum.  Sometimes one's memory embellishes and you remember the food to be much better than it actually is.  Not this time.  The food that matched my dreams along with the truly gracious, hospitable staff made a fan out of me.  I won't wait another 15 years to come back here.
author: Betty R.

description:
Most of the pastas are homemade and are delicious.  Pasta della casa  is great.  Our waiter offered to split our entres 3 ways and served us each a sampler.  I think all dinners should be served this way.

Ask for seating in the wine cellar, the ambiance is great.

Our waiter was a, dare I say, charming Frenchman who could spat off tons of facts about every bottle of wine on their extensive list.  We ordered a few nice bottles and he the brought us a glass of the reserve on the house after our meal.  He is also a monoskier and proud of it.  I think I put the monoskiing community somewhere just below scientology on the cults list.

My opinion is that the price is right at this place.  I'm generally dissapointed with Italian Food in North Beach as most seem to be a bit of a tourist trap.  I tend to gravitate to the smaller spots in Nob Hill.   But, with $18 for homemade pasta or $26 for Veal Salmitboca, its hard to complain since the food is some of the best in the city.

I'll definitely be going back.
author: Brady L.

description: Old school San Francisco at its finest.  Plus a wine list to die for.
author: Alan B.

description: Love this restaurant have eaten there many times and am never disappointed.  Great food and service and  excellent wine from their own winery.
author: John C.

description:
Went there last night for a great meal. 

First, their olive oil from their own olive trees is excellent! We started with an appetizer combination plate, which included their own house cured Prosciutto (which is awesome) which came atop a sweet piece of melon, and is a must as an appetizer.  We also had some calamari (which was OK), and a great crab stuffed artichoke, which may have been one of the best apps I have ever had.

For the mains which we all shared were equally impressive.  
1) One of the evening specials was the Osso Bucco, which was great.  Tender, and very well braised.  
2)Lamb sirloin, which was not pretty on the plate, but was expertly cooked, tender, and came in a wonderful barolo sauce.
3) Veal Saltimbocca, which was also very good.  The veal was tender, and came with the previously mentioned prosciutto.

We tried a couple of their deserts.
1) A gelato affogato, which was a vanilla gelato, topped with espresso grinds, and some Italian brandy.  This was very good.
2) Cold Zabaglione with strawberries, was excellent!

We drank a few different wines, sticking with their Petroni vineyard wines.  We had a good '05 Chardonnay,  and and excellent '03 Brunello.  Both wines very good.

We also had a couple of grappas, which should always complete any Italian meal.

Their menu is very large, and has a lot to chose from.  Normally this would be a red flag for me, but everything we had was very good.  Their service is impeccable, everyone from the waiter to the owner make you feel at home and try to do everything to make your meal a memorable one.

I will be back here again soon.
author: Danian P.

description: The old school Italian vibe of this classy joint brings a tear to the eye.  The waiters are all up there in years (aka, should have retired 20 years ago) and all wear slightly weathered tuxes, which adds to the charm.  Impeccable service from all of the staff.  Oh yeah, the food....delicious authentic Italian.  Might be one of the best puttanescas I've ever had.  Killer complimentary foccacia, with olive oil made by the owner.  On our way out, the maitre'd offered us a taste of the wine made by the owner, and it was SO GOOD, we bought 3 bottles.  I will so be back here.
author: Betsy K.

description: If I could give 0 stars, I would! This restaurant is horrible....beginning with the crappy table they gave my family outside. We were seated on a slant of a hill with a wobbly table and we asked numerous times to be moved, all of our requests were ignored. It took my 2 year old son to fall off his chair before we were even spoken too about it, and once we told our waiter what had happened his response was "so, what do you want me to do about it?" We couldn't believe how rude he was and so uncaring! We then asked to speak to the manager, who laughed when we were telling him what had happened. How do you find a 2 year old child falling and getting hurt because of the unsafe table/slanted hill you put us on funny? After we told him we didn't find it funny and that we would give the restaurant a horrible review, he showed a little emotion. We never saw our waiter again after that incident, we even flagged him down for more water and he walked away. The manager then brought out water and we explained how the waiter would not come to our table and his response was "I noticed that, that is why I am taking care of you." On top of everything else, the food itself was salty and disgusting, we all barely could eat it. We left no tip (which we never do) and will never be returning, we told all of our friends and family to NOT ever go there!!!
author: Ray B.

description:
I've lived in SF off and on for the past year so my restaurant experience in the city is novice at best.  However, I did get enough of an experience at NBR to post a few comments.

I went with my girlfriend and three of her girlfriends.  I got about three comments from various waiters and hosts about being "the man" for bringing in so many lovely ladies.  Although I had nothing to do with it, it was a good start to the evening.

The atmosphere is really nice despite the Saturday night crowd.  A very classy place, white table cloth, waiters in suits and up.

No one in the party thought the food was particularly special in spite of being a pretty pricey.

What I was most impressed with was the waitstaff.  Our waiter was really attentive to our needs in spite of the many tables he had to service.  Our group had a show to catch later that night, so he made sure we ordered dishes that would get us out in time.  Additionally, he helped me pick out a wine that worked well amongst the different tastes of the group.

All in all, go here for  the experience and be sure not to dress like a tourist, even if you are one.
author: Blake O.

description: Old school Italian cool.  Consistently great food.
author: Liss J.

description:
Had my 50th birthday party there in the Prosciutto Room (25 of us).  Food was amazing, service was wonderful.  Had called previously about corkage fee if we brought our own wine ($30).  Thought that was high, but we were really disappointed when we saw the cheapest bottle was $90!  Ended up with a bill close to $5,000 (over $2,000 in wine alone).
As a follow up to this event my son (17) sent the owner a letter asking for a donation of a gift certificate for an auction for an organization he volunteers for, mentioning my birthday, etc.  Never heard from them.  I followed up with a phone call, was told no way, they get too many requests (they pick 3 charities a year to donate to), I asked for a token donation ($25 gift cert) (hey, it gets folks in the door to spend a heck of a lot more) and he hung up on me. Needless t o say, won't go back no matter how good they are.
author: Laura M.

description:
I am a veteran San Francisco traveler.  Someone recommended this place to me so we gave it a try. Not too crowded. Promptly seated and attended to.  Then the wheels fell off.  Our waiter was a crusty veteran who exuded an air of "don't bother me".  I perused the wine list and found the pricing by bottle outrageous; at least three times retail.  Smacks of "if you are so stupid to pay these prices, we'll sell it to you". Wines by the glass a joke; limited selection and quality.  My wife, being very selective and direct about her desire for a nice thick layered lasagna was given short shrift by Mr. Gruff.  Sure enough, the lasagna arrived appearing as a deck of playing cards like a Jenny Craig diet meal. At that point my wife was upset and did not want to eat anything else.  I had spaghetti carbonara which was quite good, only after I was informed there was "no way" they would substitute pasta for potatoes on their lamb entree.  Insurmountable task for an Italian restaurant I guess.  Summary: Expensive, snotty waiter, overpriced wine and food.

8-21-10.  Returned for another try after yet another recommendation from our concierge, a completely different experience.  The prior waiter is no longer working there (my wife let her feelings known to our host when we arrived). We had a really great meal.  New York steak for my son was perfect, veal special for me topped with chopped asparagus and mushrooms, tender and delicious, linguine and clams for my wife.  All topped off by the owner's killer "Brunello de Sonoma" 2004 wine.  $22.00 a glass, an outstanding wine and surprising such a high quality wine by the glass.  Very clean and excellent service this time.
author: Mr. Helper L.

description:
My first experience with the North Beach Restaurant was for my friend's 30th birthday last September.  We were offered and accepted "family style" appetizers without being given the price....BIG mistake.  To us "family style" meant sharing a few large appetizers in the middle of the table for a reasonable price.  Instead, they served each person a small serving of their most expensive dishes and it cost each person more than the priciest entree.  When we discovered this on the bill at the end of the night, despite our outrage (and nearly $3000 bill for 30 of us) they would not budge on the price.

A few weeks later I was telling a friend about this terrible restaurant and he had just been ripped off there himself.  He, his girlfriend and their parents had accepted the "house wine" without being told that the house wine is $90 per bottle.  In every other restaurant, the house wine is either the cheapest wine or at least a good value.  Again they would not budge on the price.

I have no problem for paying for what I order, however, I believe that they systematically attempt to deceive you in order to make you pay much more than is reasonable.  This restaurant has cheated money from me and many of my friends on multiple occasions.  I strongly recommend that everyone avoid this extremely deceptive and dishonest restaurant.
author: Steve H.

description: We had a very good dinner here before going to see a concert at Bimbo's. The place was lively and noisy with a hopping bar. The waiters and bartenders were attentive and friendly, even funny and joking with us. The pasta we shared was a delicious tagliatelli pesto, and I had a delicate petrale sole stuffed with crab and shrimp. My loooovely companion had chicken picata with an unusual sauce which was delectable. A good time was had by all.
author: Tom C.

description:
With this place you either love it or hate it. I had been in there before with a group from work for lunch and it was fine. The service was ok. We then had our company christmas lunch there, and we had all of the left side that was parted off by a wall. It was kinda cramped for us. The drinks were good and the somollier was great about serving us. We never had to go up to the bar to order our drinks. There was some antipasta and calamari which was okay. Not enough of it though. We had to wait quite awhle for the first course. 
The first course came and it was just a plain salad, with a little tomato on the side, and we had no choice of dressing (?) I don't know how this worked. We usually have a menu we pick from before hand and then tell the restaurant what we will be having. We should have had a choice of soup or salad.
The next course was the pesto pasta. Although it was good, on our plates was about only six of them. That was kinda cheap. I ordered the fish which was really good. The potatoes were kinda dry and salty. (I see a pattern here from a previous post about salty foods). There were other dishes which everybody seemed to enjoy. 
The dessert was good too. In true Itallian fashion there was the Tiramisu, and other things like chocolate and cheese cake. I had the cappacino and it was not really that hot.
author: Fog City Girl L.

description: The food was excellent.  It is fairly expensive but everyone in the restaurant is very involved in making your visit enjoyable so I think that the price is justified by the food and service.
author: Craig M.

description: Service was excellent.  Food was delicious.  Very much enjoyed cannoli and lasagna.  Went with three kids and all enjoyed.
author: Bob W.

description:
I  recently had to entertain someone I did not know too well. She told me she wanted to drink a nice glass of wine in a fun setting and also have some great Italian Food. She was staying in the Fidi and wanted to walk to this place, so out went all the places I would usually go. Since NB was right down the street from  her hotel, that was the direction we headed. After a not so great glass of wine at a wine bar, we decided to give NBR a try. 
Walking in, we were greeted by a very friendly staff. The moment we sat down, the waiter came over and greeted us. When he came back to bring us our water, he went over the menu with us and made some great suggestion. I was very impressed! The food was good, the attitude of the whole restaurant was very inviting and most of all, my guest had a smile on her face. Mission accomplished!
I had heard several times that the Italian food in NB was over priced and not authentic. Since I have never been to Italy, I can't vouch for authentic, but I thought it was very tasty. As far as price, I found it to be at par with most restaurants in the city.
I will be back! :o)
author: Lisa A.

description: They had a bottle of Opus One to replace our bottle we brought in.  Ours had  the potential to be a better vintage, but theirs was already aged a little more.  Fair trade....  I remember the food being good.  I use to come here when I first moved the city.... I don't anymore.  Feels touristy.... the whole area does.
author: Demanding T.

description: Never again will I EVER EAT THERE!!!!  Talk about a disappointment.  It had been 2 yrs since i was last there and the food was great.  I went in a month ago and was sooooooo livid I had it out w/ the host when i left.  The service was awful, the food was all over priced and cold.  I had carpaccio and pasta.  For my half of the bill without a tip it was 32.00.  My pasta was cold, we didn't even get water until 30 mins into the evening, it was dreadful.  The place was also filled w/ tourists none dressed in the required attire.  The waiter literally hurled our food at us and the people seated next to us.  At all costs avoid this establishment like the plague!!!!
author: Nicole F.

description: My situation was the same with Steve H.  That was exactly what happend to us for our friend's b-day dinner.  As we were settling down, the waiter just started talking about appetizers.  Little did we know what was happening.  We thought he was reciting the specials of the day, which anyone rarely pays attention to, especially when our party is over 10 ppl.  Anyway, bad dining experience and I will not go back there.  I have a feeling that we were forced to have whatever they give us.  The pastas are okay, but for that price, it was not worth it.   For a $100 bottle of wine, it did not taste well at all.
author: AhLin C.

description: The one thing that my family liked was the italian authenticity, ie the waiters. However, two of the six orders at our table had to be sent back. One was bc the veal parmisian was cold and two ,because they put things in my mom's salad that weren't on the menu- and were things that she doesn't eat (pork). There were no apologies. Reheating my boyfriend's veal parmisiana took forever  to reheat it. Taking the pork out of my mom's salad took forever and they did not remove all of it. And then since they did that, the fish that was the entree on top of her salad came back cold and dry. She had them warm it and on the third time she received her food, it was still not warm and was dry.
author: Sara L.

description: I was excited about this restaurant, and used up a "fancy dinner" card with boyfriend on it, and it sucked. We ended up splurging on wine to cover up the bad food. The decor, the scene, the high prices, kind of ridiculous for the sub-par Italian food and service. How strange that it's here amongst some amazing restaurants. Save your money and go to Mangarosa, or L'Osteria del Forno.
author: Anna B.

description:
I went to North Beach Restaurant the other day with a huuuuge group.  I had family in town from the midwest that wanted pasta/carbs (my uncle was doing a triathlon the next day) so we decided to hit up North Beach Restaurant.  I was SO impressed with how they took care of our group.  We had almost 20 people, but with my family, that seems more like 40 or 50.  We had our own private room in the basement (the cigar room I believe).  They also have a fancy wine room and the prosciutto room with hams  HANGING from the ceiling.  They didn't require us to sign a contract or set a limited menu.  They also helped us with a great appetizer and dessert tray that was much easier to deal with than figuring out between 20 people what each person wanted to eat.  The food was great too.  I had "salmon my way" and it was, quite simply, my way.  I guess if you order it, then it would be salmon your way too, not salmon Caitlin's way, but it made me feel special anyway.  The staff was great, the food was good, and my insane family made it even better.  I'm sure there are other restaurants in North Beach with equivelant Italian food,  but for a big group, I would DEFINITELY recommend this  place.


(PS I don't think the note above about cash only is true...)
author: Caitlin D.

description: This place is just a sexy, bright, graceful little gem in North Beach... and I cannot wait to go back! We sat right in the window, and Daniel was our waiter, very courteous and knowledgeable. I had the caeser salad (tangy and light), the eggplant parmesan (very flavorful, served with sauteed spinach and broccoli mixture which was very good) and the hot zabiglione for dessert. For impressing family or a business lunch, this is a true taste of old-school Little Italy, Tuscan style. Menu is really quite varied and offers something for everyone!
author: Rebecca A.

description:
This place blew me away. Admittedly I do not dine out frequently and have not experienced many North Beach restaurants but this place is special. From the first moment I was greeted at the door with a friendly smile that was genuine and made me feel welcome, throughout the awesome meal, I knew I was having an exceptional dining experience. Here's my breakdown:
FOOD: AWESOME   I had the lasagna and it was melt in your mouth delicious. For dessert I had the fabulous cheese cake that was cooked with rum (I think). I didn't know whether to eat it or worship it! My wife had seafood and loved it.
SERVICE: TOPNOTCH  Our waiter was prompt, professional and genuinely friendly. The place was swarming with staff in tuxedos. We never waited for anything.
AMBIANCE: EXCELLENT The main plus was the attitude of the staff. You can tell when someone is being polite and friendly because it's their job but everyone here presented a genuine interest in our party as customers.
PARKING: Did you ever try to find a parking place in North Beach? You either end up in a straight-jacket or at some overpriced parking garage. Let the Valets in front of the restaurant park your car for less than you could in any garage in the area.

I highly recommend North Beach restaurant for a great dining experience. It's expensive but who cares when you leave feeling fantastic.
author: Dennis N.

description:
My favorite italian food in all of San Francisco.

So elegant... feels like an older, romantic Italy..
waiters are dressed in black and white tuxes, valet makes parking super convenient, and the ambiance is remarkable.

The best part?  They house-cure their own proscuitto. 
BEST PROSCUITTO I've ever had in my life. 

Great minestrone soup as well.

Minus one star for having arrogant and cocky waiters every time I come.
author: A. K.

description: Easily one of the best in SF! Great food, great atmosphere. Don't go if you aren't willing to drop some coin though or don't like to dine! I recommend it to anyone who wants to have a relaxing, 2 hour dinner while eating great Italian food with an unbelievable wine menu .  All the employees will take care of you if you treat them well! I can eat there every night- its that good.....
author: Dave A.

description: The rape of cuisine, for $25 a person, minimum.  The mushroom risotto was like sea water, if sea water contained flavorless "wild" mushrooms.  The eggplant parmesan was boring; I should have brought a novel to read for some stimulation.  Also, it was the size of 2 silver dollar pancakes.  (Yes, I realize these two ideas are in conflict.)  I asked the guy if they made the spinach ravioli in-house, and he kind of halfheartedly nodded, while consciously trying to maintain eye contact.  Yeah right.  The waiters were in unnecessary suits.
author: Mike F.

description: Old school Italian. Great food and service
author: Kenneth B.

description: I went to North Beach Restaurant for dinner on a Saturday night with 3 of my girlfriends. Our waiter was great - we never had empty water or wine glasses. The food came quickly and it was delicious. It was a little on the pricey side, but definitely worth it. We were there for over 2 hours, and we never felt like we were rushed to finish and leave. I will definitely be back!
author: Amy A.

description: Ok the calamari frittis here are soooooooo good!!! they come wrapped in white linen- and so fresh they were just hauled out of the fryer!!! Zest it with the lemon or dip in their marinara sauce!  If you like Osso bucco- its also wonderful here :-)  Tutti buono
author: Arissa C.

description: The waiter did it for me.  The food was good, but not really 5 star for me, but that waiter... he was a character and a half.  I LOVED him!  He was so much fun.  We asked him which he suggested based on two dishes which looked good, and he picked one and said in the most italian accent "It is gonna be so deliscious and if I have chosen wrong, you donna pay for it!"  Of course, it was wonderful.
author: Mason G.

description:
My parents used to go here before I was even born, so it's no surprise that I've always loved the North Beach.   This is the perfect place to go for a 2nd date, to take parents and family, friends, co-workers, etc.  I still kick myself that I didn't call early enough to get the private room for my rehearsal dinner!

Beautiful restaurant with high ceilings and nice ambiance.  Lively, friendly wait staff.  Best seats are in the windows which makes it perfect for people watching. 

Highly recommend: 
- House salad (don't know what the dressing is, but delicious)
- Pasta Della Casa.  I've been ordering this since I can remember (and I'm talking like, 5 years old)
- Petrale Sole
- My husband loves the tortellini in cream sauce.  I always steal bites from him
-Risotto

Order the Affogato for dessert.  It's one shot of espresso over one scoop of gelato.  Delicious.  and don't forget to top off your evening with a blended limoncello drink.

Enjoy!
author: Christina S.

description:
Went on a busy Sat night and didn't have to wait longer than a couple minutes for a table for 2.  The service was excellent... we especially liked how the server gave us suggestions for our appetizer and beer & wine.  
The cheese appetizer with balsamic vinegar and fresh tomatoes was amazing.  Thanks to the server for suggesting it!
The homemade pasta was also a delight.  I especially liked the spinach ravioli and the gnocchi (gnocchi is so good when not from a box!).
After a basket of bread, an appetizer and a plate of pasta - no room for dessert.  Sorry, can't comment.
The ambiance is nice (date worthy), the service was great, and the food was fantastic.  The only downside was the bathroom... it was a single stall.  I went in just to wash my hands and got a nose full of unpleasantness.  I washed as fast as I could and prayed there'd be no one in line thinking it was me who did it.  I hate that!
author: Lil B.

description: Truly a hot spot for people who know absolutely nothing about decent Italian food.  The point is not to eat, but to be seen getting out of your limo, or requisite fancy luxury car, have it valet parked and be ushered into a great looking building.  I walk by this place daily and it screams "LOOK AT ME!"  and make my way to a place without Prince Gavin I scoping out his next teenage dessert.  If they put this place on a back street nobody would bother with it, but at the intersection of Green, Stockton and Columbus, you can show lots of people you don't know how important you think you are.
author: Rob K.

description:
awesome spot- serves late- easy cab access- old school northern Italian-
they push the owners wine too much- but go and spend some time- you will love it
author: Aaron E.

description: It's been several years since I've been here, but I had one of the greatest Italian meals at North Beach Restaurant I've ever had in my life.  I still think about it today.  I told my husband we have to go now that we are living in the area again.  Last time I was there the service was top notch, we did not have a reservation & they were very busy.  Once we were seated we were treated like we were the only patons in the place.  The meal was pricey, but I am still thinking about it.  I will update my review as soon as we go again.
author: Debbie M.

description:
So many better places in North Beach. Self-important host, uninspiring food, no attention to presentation. 

Seriously, take a stroll up Columbus and you'll find 10 better places. (Like Michelangelo Restaurant, right up the street).
author: jason e.

description:
This was our third choice of a restaurant.  The first two were way too busy and/or we couldn't find parking.  They have valet parking here.  A real plus for North Beach especially during the tourist season.  

The ambiance is really nice in this restaurant.  The color scheme was relaxing.  High ceilings made it not noisy even though it is a large restaurant.  You are greeted by someone in a suit and several other employees make you feel welcome from the moment you walk in.  The waiters (all male) are dressed in black suits and most are older.  The bar is a happening place and the bartender has a good sense of humor about the effusive Italians working there.  

The food was pretty good.  I had the spaghetti vodka and it was delicious.  The minnestroni soup was excellent.  The escargot only so so.  The caeser salad was good (suggestion:  need to put shaved parmesan on it rather than the strips of cheese they use now). The desserts were alright--nothing special but worth the price.  

The only thing I didn't like was I felt a bit rushed.  The waiter was obviously wanting to flip our table.  He never stepped over the line but he sure came close to it.  

This is a good date place.  Your date will walk out of the restaurant feeling good.
author: Karen B.

description: Very old school.  The fish is great.  I've had the petrale sole, stuffed and not, and both variations were good.  They also have an appetizer/antipasto type dish that has a good selection of flavors.  It's really a meal in itself so I'd only order if more than 2 people are in your party.  Their waiting area is very small so that's annoying and I think it's weird when I am the youngest person in an establishment on a weekend night.
author: Seong P.

description: This place is great for Italian food lovers! The meals are flavorful and generous, with plenty of options. My favorites are: the porcini risotto, the cannelloni, and the best ever, ever, ever - and sometimes hard to find in the US - the cold zabaione (or zabaglione, or zabajone) for dessert . Oh, my... it's to die for!!!! When we are in San-Fran, the North Beach Restaurant is a must go for us.
author: K D.

description: The food here is solidly good, but not as excellent as one might expect. It tends to be rather loud and crowded, which in some ways is not so nice, but in other ways creates a very "large Italian family dinner" environment. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable, especially about the wine.
author: Barbs J.

description: This is the best italian restaurant I've ever been to. If that doesn't mean much to you then let me reinforce it by saying that I've been to many, many heavy-weight italian eateries in Rome, Las Vegas, LA, and SF. The service is the perfect untangible that really brings this place over the top. Of course, the food is ridiculously good... duh! The prices are a little heavy in the pocket but you can afford to... you can't afford not to try this place at least once!
author: Andrew W.

description: I came here with my boyfriend and parents for appetizers and wine before going to see a musical at the Post Street Theatre. The wine was amazing and the food tasty. We shared the antipasto toscano which included home-cured prosciutto, salame, cheeses, marinated calamari, veal shank, & beans. We also split an order of escargots. So buttery and delicious! We had a nice time and I would love to come back for dinner one day!
author: Nicole F.

description: The food was great and the service was amazing.  Each time our wine glasses approached empty the waiter noticed and refilled our glasses for us.  The ambiance is nice and provides for a pleasant dining experience.
author: Andrew N.

description: Yum!! I just got home from having my third absolutely delicious meal from this fine establishment. Tonight there was a caprese salad special that was definitely on steroids, because the mozzarella was the biggest, most fabulous piece of cheese I have ever seen and the tomatoes were as big as salad plates. For dinner, I did have the veal (I know it's bad, but I can't resist it from a good place) and it was the tastiest Veal Milanese I've ever had. Dessert was equally as good as the others and I was lucky enough to split three different things: zabaglione with strawberries, spumoni, and creme caramel (my favorite). Overall, this place is fabulous, consistent, and friendly and I can't wait to go again!
author: Allison B.

description: A great place to take a date to show off.  It is a ritzy restaurant with decent food and good service.  Definetly will return.  Not a romantic spot as it is very bright and noisy.
author: Jose C.

description: The Pasta Della Casa was just so good.  We were treated really nice and were given a taste of a nice red wine--we went for the more affordable Chianti though.  The waiter couldn't have been nicer and we had a great experience here.
author: Franklin R.

description: Greeted at the entrance by a nice little old man that you wouldn't expect to be your host. That was pleasant. Our waiter was a bit impatient and seemed a bit overworked. The bread came warm, oil and balsamic at the table, my sweet wine was kinda gross so i returned it for some port which was much better (although n@ couldn't stand it!). He kinda gave me a hard time about it... and for some reason blamed n@ which we were perplexed about! haha... anyway, the most important part of the meal (the meal itself) was pretty damn good! I had the homemade cannelloni (which I highly recommend). All in all, the meal made up for everything else. We didn't have dessert cuz we rushed out to make it to the Hagen Daaz shop before it closed (a whole other adventure). I'll give North Beach a B.
author: Nate G.

description:
I enjoyed dinner at NBR last week. Our large group was seated in the Wine Cellar, which was a lovely venue for the evening. The wait staff were extremely attentive and professional.

Our first course was a nice plating of grilled prawns, caprese salad and the real star... house cured prosciutto with melon. The prosciutto at NBR was the best I have ever had! It was the perfect balance of texture, flavor and saltiness.

For our second course we sampled pillow-soft gnocchi and a delicate seafood rigatoni pasta. Both were very good.

I chose Veal Saltimbocca for my main entree. However, I was full at that point so I did not really get to enjoy the dish.

The tiramisu was not anything special and so I wouldn't particularly recommend it.

Overall, my experience was great and I would return to dine here again.
author: Patty C.

description:
You simply cannot forgo the escargot.  It's incredible.  Not to mention the carpaccio....deelish.   

The service is very friendly and the wine list quite broad.  

It is a little pricey, however, for what you get - $29 for an average serving of linguine with porcini and scallops.... a bit much for a pasta that had less than half a dozen scallops and just a few porcini's.

They have quite the selection of veal - which usually would be enough to make me pass on by.  But the steak selection is quite poor.  

However, I do recommend as I have enjoyed both my visits immensely.
author: Lauren W.

description: Very upscale and very delicious.  I loved our server.  Older gentleman who treated me like a princess.  I loved it!  My friend and I drank vino and ate steak.  Yum yum.  I will go back again someday.
author: Noneya B.

description: We were here this past weekend. The taxi cab driver dropped us off at the door when we asked for a good Italian place for dinner. No reservations, no problemo. We sat right down, the waiter told us the specials and served us very quickly and with high energy. We had no complaints. We look forward to going there again in the near future.
author: Mary M.

description:
One of my faves in my neighborhood.

The staff is excellent, they treat you like family.

The food is wonderful as well.

Ah..so many good memories here.
author: Nicole R.

description: It was very nice to walk around North Beach and Telegraph Hill for the evening and end up here. It wasn't crowded because there were only 30 minutes serving time left, but it was good to get out of the hustle and bustle of NB, just briefly. If I went for dinner, I'd definitely wear something a little nicer. Waiters were nice, friendly, and in ties and jackets. We had the ice cream torta [yum!] and the chocolate mousse [yummmmmm!] and I'd totally go back for drinks and dessert if nothing else. :)
author: Angela H.

description: This is somewhat of a pricey restaurant, but they have the best Spaghetti Bolognese in the bay area.  Very rich & authentic taste, but the portions are kind of small.   So eat lots of foccacia bread with your pasta.   Great location & atmosphere, but parking sucks.
author: Lawrence L.

description: Classic Italian...what could be better! The first time I ate here was 1985, I went back years later and it wasn't as good. However, a couple years ago I thought I'd give it another try and it was off the hook...been going at least every month since and the food and service have been off the hook!
author: Greg T.

description:
ABSOLUTELY PHENOMENAL!!!!! THE BEST ITALIAN FOOD IN SAN FRANCISCO!!! I have been to this place numerous times while in San Francisco, and without question it is my mom's and my favorite restaurant in the city.  To start off with the bread is  fabulous, and I think a restaurant's bread is a preview to the rest of the meal. If they have good bread, it's going to be a good meal; however, if the bread is not the best, the meal will be mediocre.  To start I get the polenta soup, which is to die for delicious!  I love polenta, and this is the only place I've ever known of that has transformed polenta into a soup.  Then I always get one of their amazing pastas for my main course.  All of their pastas are wonderful, but my favorite is definitely the Gnocchi. 
My mom gets the chicken livers, and absolutely loves them.  My dad has had delectable fish there before, so you can't go wrong with anything that you order.  The desserts are also a must try.  North Beach Restaurant is AMAZING!!!
author: Ali V.

description:
We were at the North Beach festival over this past weekend and decided to try this restaurant instead of eating on the street. We were starving and thought this would be a good choice... we were wrong! 
As we were seated, we felt as if the waiter was already pissed off and didn't want to be there. It was 3:02, and they wouldn't let us order fromt he lunch menu (which is understandable) but after we asked, even MORE attitude began. It took forever for them to take our order, they only refilled our water after asking twice and when we asked for a couple small plates for the calamari, he pretty much rolled his eyes. The food was waaaaay too salty, so I didn't even a quarter of my pasta. When I told our waiter, he totally ignored me. In the end, lunch for 2 of us (with no drinks) was almost $100 and I left hunrgy and pissed off. I wait on tables for a living and pride myself on being a very generous tipper (40% for great service). For the 1st time, I left 10% and my BF thought it was too much. I'll never go back again, and urge all of you to do the same!
author: Jeanna L.

description:
What an embarrassing disappointment.  I recommended this restaurant to friends in the city for a great meal at a cozy place.  

As soon as they walked in the host ignored them, when they were finally seated they were stuck in a dark corner and ignored again.  The waiter finally appeared asked for the drink order and disappeared.  

15 minutes later still, no drinks he takes their order.  

Another 10 minutes no drinks, my friends decide to leave, they catch the waiter to cancel their order and he smirks okay. 

I do not understand this type of service.  Am I mistaken or isn't San Francisco the place that survives on tourists and not just it's regulars?  

My friend felt as if they wait staff had sized them up to not be able to afford eating there, little do they know if she wanted to she could have bought the damn place and closed it down.

They deserve no stars.
author: Cecilia C.

description: Pretty good. Expensive, though. And the portions are kind of small. One thing I must say, however, is that those 5 little chunks of home-fry style potatoes that they gave me were DELICIOUS. If only they gave me more...
author: Michelle G.

description: This place is fantastic!  The waitstaff are incredibly professional and experienced and the food is great.  The prosciutto with melon is the best.    My fiance and I try to go here whenever our pocketbooks will allow.  The prices aren't cheap, but you are getting a bargain in quality.  If you are really lucky, you will get to meet the owner, Lorenzo, who is truly the warmest man.  And of course, you must try some of his wine, the "Poggio."  I like to try a lot of wines, but I always come back to this one as my favorite.
author: Kate B.

description: OK, I know everyone loves this place.  And I do agree that the food is very good, but here are a few complaints: 1.  The waiter tried to pour us $100 bottles of some family wine, all without our asking (needless to say he did not tell us the price--one of my wise dining companions knew about this ploy).  2.  The waiter followed this by trying to foist both caesar salad and other apps on the entire table, want it or not.  3.  The most outrageous thing, bar none, was the $30 corkage we were charged for the one bottle we brought, never mind that we also spent $140 on two bottles of wine in addition.  Needless to say, when we looked at the $400+ bill and saw the $30 corkage, I was a little miffed.  The food is great, but pricey, and the waiters need some lessons in personal space and patience.
author: Lucas M.

description: I thought this place was pretty bad.  I thought that the waiters had bad manners and my eggplant parmesan tasted like soap.  I probably won't go here again.  The only great thing about this place is the wine selection.  Great wine.
author: Joanna S.

description: Good service, Good selections of wine, great bread,  fresh huge prawns cocktail, awesome seafood pasta, Tiramis was ok , might have little too much of ameretto instead of rum. The only thing i was not too happy about was, they wanted us out of the restaurant quick because people were waiting for seats, we got our check even before we finish dessert. Also had to chuck down the bottle of wine. The food is great here but if you want to have a nice long dinner, dont bring a date here.
author: Daniel W.

description: Okay...my husband and I are not professional taste testers or anything...but we expected much better after being told to go to this "tasty place."  Do not go here, unless you are up for "fast food" Italian.  Disgusting Italian food and hideous service!!!!  Complete tourist trap!  (P.S.  My husband's mother is a first generation Italian immigrant, if that helps talk you out of going here.)
author: Joy G.

description: Coming from Chicago (which you know we love food in Chi-town) This place was by far - hands down the best restaurant I visited when I was in San Fran. Expect to drop some dough. Service was beyond expectations. Wine list was extensive and food really was good. I would definitely go here again next visit.
author: Crystal S.

description:
Wanted to like this place as the serves are wonderfully friendly and warm. And the restaurant has a charming old-fashioned feel. But the food is really not special at all. In fact, some dishes were downright disappointing. And for $35, I expect a better veal sorrento, with fresh tomatoes and a thicker cut of veal. Maybe that's a new way of cutting costs, but if I want to eat paper-thin slices of meat, I can get carpaccio. 

Go with the pastas if you come here. Better value for your money.
author: jennifer s.

description: Not so good. The food was just okay, the decor was cheesy, as were the waiters. And only one toilet in the lady's room just isn't good enough. And the bathroom wasn't exactly clean. The bill, however, was HUGH. Definately NOT worth the money. Not even close. The only redeeming quality is it's a good place to take the parents (bland food, decent, if cheesy, service). I think this place is really geared for tourists.
author: G G.

description: The food is absolutely delicious.  This is the only restaurant in the US that  home cures it's prosciutto and it is fabulous.  I have to say the melon & prosciutto appetizer was a little expensive for only getting 2 pieces of melon.  I had the scallops for dinner and they were great. My companions had the lamb chops, lamb tenderloin & veal scallopini.  All were excellent.  After dinner the waiter took us down to the cellar where they cure the prosciutto which was very interesting. It is right in the center of North Beach, and worth trying out.
author: Nancy C.

description: This place makes me happy,  happy,  happy.  I live in Seattle so am only in here once or twice a year but they always remember me and treat me very well!  Back here in Seattle,  I dream about their wonderful chicken livers and those really good little roasted potatoes that others have mentioned.  Has anyone said anything about their amazing super-creamy mozzarella cheese which comes in the Caprese?  YOW is it good...I could live on the stuff along with a few tomatoes and whatnot.  I will post one little warning/gripe...the wine list is pretty dang expensive,  as others have pointed out.  But you can find good cheaper (under $50)  bottles if you poke through the list long enough.  Best time to go is late at night after the noisy dinner crowd has left...and don't go on Valentine's Day either,  which is when we happened to be in town for the recent visit!
author: Taylor B.

description: We had an excellent dinner at North Beach Restaurant this evening.  The service was terrific, our table was by the front window.  The highlights were the calamari in vinegar, lamb chops, spinach salad, chicken, and fresh pasta with olive oil, butter, and mushrooms.  Ambiance was lovely.
author: Mark L.

description: Extremely overpriced for so-so food...sort of a double edged sword as the portions are nicely sized, but then again, the food is average at best, so you are just getting a lot of so-so food.   The maitre d' seemed like he was on crack he was so hyper..when we checked in, he ran off so fast that he was like 50 feet away before we realized he was "showing us" to our table.
author: Marina F.

description:
This is one of the most exraordinary restaurants I have ever eaten at  I would say I'm moderately picky, but there are a few cardinal rules any good restaurant should abide by:
1: ambience--perfect at NBR!  feels very classy inside, not cheap, certainly not ostentatious.  i think this setting would satisfy the first generation italian american (myself) or the trendy couple looking for delicious authetentic cuisine.
2:service-i don't ask for much, but what i do ask for seems to be sorely lacking at many restaurants.  there's an old saying: "act like you've been there before."  it connotes class and experience.  in the case of NBR, experience exudes from the waiters. simply, they know what they are doing.  when they recommend something it's because they know it's flipping delicious. if you have a question, they answer it with years of experience behind their reasoning.
3. food: my italian mother has fed my belly for the past 30 something years.  i have visited italy yearly since the age of 6 and have tasted some of the most authentic cuisine that the boot-shaped country can offer.   this place is legit.  the pasta is ridiculously fresh and hearty.  the meats are tender and flavorful.  don't get me started on the veal.  any reader who has had bad veal knows how easy it is to make veal taste bad.  NBR has the most exquisitely tender, juicy, flavorful veal I've ever had.  
4. price:  reasonable given the aforementioned attributes.  you are paying for quality.  

A true five star restaurant.  You will leave this place thinking "damn, that was some freaking delicious food!!!"  furthermore, you'll remember the "experience" which is just as wonderful as the food.
author: Aaron S.

description:
We came here for appetizers and drinks on a beautiful sunny afternoon, based only on the fact that they had open tables outside and the front of the restaurant is positioned such that it was in the sun when we walked by.  But I this place screams "black-tie olive garden" to me.

I can't judge the dinner, but we did have wine, bread, and a lame shrimp cocktail. I think it's unfortunate if you are going to a presumably nice, somewhat costly restaurant and they put stale bread out in front of you. Also, the servers are kind of strange, and the atmosphere inside seemed like it would be pretty stuffy. 

The appetizer list was pretty weak (hence the ordering of a shrimp cocktail- is that even Italian?).
